I have surgery in about 10 days and hoping for a similarly impressive pathology. 10% of pattern 4 in your final pathology is pretty good. Tim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman Today I had my MRI with contrast done at MSKCC. They are very thorough. They gave me a shot of something-or-other that is used to quiet the bowel, to minimize movement. And just before I went into the room, they took a wand and moved it over my body, to make sure I didn't have any metal inside me besides the 2 stents that I told them about. After the test was done, the technician who was a friendly dude made a comment that really surprised me. He said "in all the years I've been working here, I don't recall ever seeing a recurrence of prostate cancer." I'm like, "WHAT?" But I didn't respond or persue it, I just chose to believe it because we all believe what we want to believe. Now I wait for the results. With a PSA of .03 as of end of May, I'd be shocked if it picked up any prostate cancer. But I figure, exactly for the fact that I'm not worried about it, they will probably find some collateral unexpected thing that is worse, like bladder cancer, or some other disaster. But if I didn't think that, I wouldn't be me. One thing I know, if they do find that, I'm not having a cystoscope. No matter what. Ever. The MRI was done only because the RO wanted a baseline, just in case I continue to see PSA rising. Guess I'll call next week for the results. I'm too scared to sign up for the MSKCC patient portal Hey, Pratoman - Maybe I shouldn't ask, but what's wrong with a cystoscope ? I have Robotic RP in a few days (Next Tuesday) and I believe my surgeon ordered a cystoscope on the day of my followup appointment, I'm assuming to check to see how the bladder is healing to determine if it is safe to have my catheter removed. Is it painful, dangerous, etc ... ? Tim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Busby I was going over my pathology report before my meeting with doc tomorrow. My report states: The tumor infiltrates as discrete, infiltrative, compressed, irregular glands as well as cribriforming sheets and glomeruloid structures and involves the prostate bilaterally from apex to mid-base. I have been researching cribriforming cancer and found the following studies and info: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25189638 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4656017/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5861292/ https://www.archivesofpathology.org/...a.2018-0005-RA https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4779761/ The first article states: In conclusion, cribriform growth in Gleason grade 4 is a strong prognostic marker for distant metastasis and disease-specific death in patients with Gleason score 7 prostate cancer at radical prostatectomy. It seems that fairly recently, the staging and reporting of prostate cancer has changed and it has been recommended that cribriforming patterns be reported on biopsy and pathology reports (as gleason 4). I'm certainly going to go over this with my doc and maybe get some more info from the pathologist. One of the articles linked above states that in the study, they measured the area of cribriforming cancer and found that when the sample had greater than or equal to 25 square mm of cribriforming pattern, all subjects (100%) had verified metastasis. Not looking good for me. I find it interesting to see how the diagnosing, reporting and grading of prostate cancer is changing. I also researched glomeruloid structures but there is no conclusive data on prognosis other than it's associated with more aggressive forms of cancer. I find this fascinating. My post RP pathology did mention it - it specifically stated "without cribiform". So I was curious and did some research on it and pretty much found out the same stuff you discovered and was happy it wasn't an issue for my pathology. You are doing to right thing by learning all you can about your particular situation so you'll be more informed when you talk to your doctor. - Tim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by joseywales Brothers, At my cancer conference I asked my doctor about activities or foods I should avoid. He said, "Don't worry about anything." I started doing a bit of reading and made an appointment with a nutritionist. I know diet is not going to cure my cancer, but if there are things that contributed to it it seems logical to slash them. Dairy and red meet seem like good candidates. I weighed in at 123lbs clothed. That's a little light for me. Body fat was estimated at 16.8 and BMI at 19.8 Here's what the nutritionist said: I'd like to get you up to 130 or 135 pre-treatment because you will lose some weight with any treatment. Let's try to add lean muscle Reduce cardio and increase weight training. Eat lean protein. Eat more fruits and vegetables. Drink plenty of water. Eat two eggs for breakfast. Eat legumes, but no more than 8oz per meal. Chicken and fish are good. Eat wild caught fish over farm raised. Have half a protein shake in the morning and half in the evening. Continue with B12 and multi-vitamins. Add D3 and probiotics. The goal is to consume 70-80g of protein per day. Whole grains are good. I asked about eggs, because I had heard some mixed things about them. She said they were good. I asked about sugar. "Sugar feeds cancer," she said. My uncle, who had throat cancer had already told me this and I thought it odd she did not bring it up. I asked about sugar in protein shakes. She said, "Get one with Stevia." So, here are my questions: I had heard that grains in general cause inflammation and inflammation is not good. What can you tell me about whole grains? It seems like if cancer loves sugar it would love stevia just as much. Am I incorrect in this hypothesis? I haven't had good luck finding much on eggs. MDA's website says they have gotten a bad rap but are good for you. I know they contain a lot of choline and had read something about choline being used in PET scans because it goes to the cancer. I did some reading. Even broccoli contains choline. What can you tell me about eggs? If anyone has any thoughts or recommendations, please let me know. Thanks! Josey "When things look bad, and it looks like you're not gonna make it, you've gotta get mean. I mean mad dog mean, because if you lose your head in a fight you neither win nor live. That's just the way it is." I have studied nutrition informally for many years due to my type 2 diabetes (and later PCa) and can give you my thoughts on the items above ... You asked about grains. Well, some grains may be OK if you don't have diabetes but grains in general turn into sugar and raise blood sugar so they could feed cancer and also cause inflamation. My personal opinion is that everyone would do better with less grains and diabetics should eliminate them alltogether (as I did). By the way, as a type 2 diabetic, removing grains was the best thing I ever did to lower my blood sugar. In the standard american diet, every american dish contains some grains usually and this is not necessary doing anyone any good. Stevia is OK because it does not raise blood sugar - it is a herb, not a sugar. Also check out Erythritol and to a lesser extent, xylitol - both of these are sugar alcohols which doesn't affect blood sugar much if at all but xylitol in particular and erythritol to a lesser extent could cause a laxitive effect if too much is eaten at a time. If you have a dog, I believe it is xylitol that you have to watch out for because it could be fatal to dogs since they can't digest it but the issue doesn't exist in humans. I used to bake cakes with only xylitol and they tasted just like sugar. Though cakes are problematic unless you can find a grain free cake which perhaps uses almond or some other grain-free flour rather than white grain-based flour. I can't weigh in on eggs because I don't like them so I may be biased if I do. But eggs are probably OK. There is some research that animal protein may affect Prostate Cancer but I think most if the problem centers around red meat. Much of the scientific literature on PCa and nutrition suggest a link to Red Meat and PCa. I would also recommend staying away from dairy as it could be problematic due to casein and cheese in particular is very addicting. Interestingly, for me I was eating Vegan from the time of diagnosis with PCa and my robotic surgery and between that 3 month period, my PSA didn't increase that fast, only a few tenths of a point as I recall. However, I started eating meat and probably more red meat than I should about a year after my surgery and my PSA is starting to climb (Not much but .02 in 3 months) and perhaps that would have been slowed if I had eaten Vegan instead. I don't however think anyone has to go vegan to do good with Prostate Cancer, I suspect it's a good idea to stay away from Red Meat or only eat it once or twice a month and the rest of the time, eat chicken or a vegan dish. Of all of the scientific literature I've looked at, I can't find anything bad said about poultry (Chicken, turkey, etc ...). In fact, I looked at a few studies recently that said there was no link between poultry consumption and PCa. Of there's definitely a benefit to adding more vegetables to your diet or eating some meals a week vegan and no meat at all. Nowadays, there are many vegan meat substitutes such as soybean pasta (Which I like) and bean pasta (also good if you can get over the black color). I would stay away anything with soy protein isolate or anything like that because it's highly processed and may have health consequences. There are also many recipes on the internet for vegan meat substitutes that you make from scratch - these are the best and most healthiest because you know what goes into them. Couple of other things you may want to look into - Consider adding tumeric root to some of your dishes, also fresh garlic and fresh ginger root, all Organic if possible. Also green tea (Like Matcha) is good too. All of these help decrease inflammation which could improve a cancer outcome. I want to mention I'm not a nutritionist but only a concerned citizen trying to improve my own health as much as possible and live as long as I can. Hope this helps - these are my personal opinions which could change over time if new research comes to light. Tim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Trex Dino wtdedula ... I really do like my URO, and the RO I saw yesterday I liked too. What stood out with my RO yesterday is that he agreed that I should get all the information I could from the other RO and two surgeons I am scheduled to see in order for me to figure out the best treatment plan for myself. Yesterday's RO was factual and to the point sharing his opinion with confidence and never gave me the impression it was his way or the highway. In addition to my diet from my URO ... I really need to give credit to my wife (of 35+ years) who is well read, informed and supportive of what is good for me with my diet and supplements. My wife allows me to veer a little off course for my mental health then nudges me back in line (nudge = kick in the ass). Blessings of being married to an Irish Newfie woman. Awesone, DT looks you're well taken care of on all fronts . I'm in search of a good RO too though not for initial treatment like you, but for possible BCR. If I end up needing radiation, I have high hopes that an RO can knock this cancer out for good due to my fairly favorable pathology. I have my initial RO #1 appt. in about a week. Will likely call a few more next week to get differing opinions. Hopefully I can settle on one I really like and trust like you. Wishing you the best of success no matter what treatment you chose. Your nutrition strategy should help with your success. I'll probably switch to nearly 100% vegetarian until I determine what my PSA is doing and if I'll need radiation in the event it could help slow the growth. Tim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Trex Dino When I was recently DX my URO said to cut out red meat, dairy and follow a veggie based diet ... allowing for occasional wild salmon. I cut out as much sugar products such as any sweets, pastas, breads and alcohol (though fudge with two or three small glasses of red wine a week). Breakfast is the only time a have a little dairy having cottage cheese with flax oil, medley of fresh fruit, dash of cinnamon and walnuts. Lunch is a variety of fresh vegetables with avocado oil, vinegar and tumeric. Dinner is mainly veggies with occasional small amount of meat. The other night I had a homemade tomato sauce over spaghetti squash with two very small meatballs (wife and daughter had pasta with a side of squash) along with a garden salad. Once a week have a boiled egg as a snack. Dessert is usually a big spoonful of almond butter with chopped almonds and a glass of almond or coconut milk. Beverages is copious amount of coffee in the morning with water throughout the day. Once a week is cheat night. This Sunday it will be take out Chinese food. Really needed to get on this diet as want to drop another 10 lbs to run (slow run) a 12k on May 5th. Td - That sounds like an excellent and logical plan to me. I like your doctor and I wish I could find a doctor with good advice like that. It's OK to indulge once in a while (Few times a month) but I wouldn't do it every day. Tim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Trex Dino wtdedula ... I really do like my URO, and the RO I saw yesterday I liked too. What stood out with my RO yesterday is that he agreed that I should get all the information I could from the other RO and two surgeons I am scheduled to see in order for me to figure out the best treatment plan for myself. Yesterday's RO was factual and to the point sharing his opinion with confidence and never gave me the impression it was his way or the highway. In addition to my diet from my URO ... I really need to give credit to my wife (of 35+ years) who is well read, informed and supportive of what is good for me with my diet and supplements. My wife allows me to veer a little off course for my mental health then nudges me back in line (nudge = kick in the ass). Blessings of being married to an Irish Newfie woman. Awesone, DT looks you're well taken care of on all fronts . I'm in search of a good RO too though not for initial treatment like you, but for possible BCR. If I end up needing radiation, I have high hopes that an RO can knock this cancer out for good due to my fairly favorable pathology. I have my initial RO #1 appt. in about a week. Will likely call a few more next week to get differing opinions. Hopefully I can settle on one I really like and trust like you. Wishing you the best of success no matter what treatment you chose. Your nutrition strategy should help with your success. I'll probably switch to nearly 100% vegetarian until I determine what my PSA is doing and if I'll need radiation in the event it could help slow the growth. Tim

Posts.Content: Hello All; I am wondering who you followup with during the years after RP surgery - Your surgeon, your urologist, etc ... ? Am wondering if this is safe or if I should seek care from another surgeon, or urologist or someone else (Who)? Tim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ready2Fight Hi Tim. You should be seeing an RO now. Personally I wouldn't waste my time with a NP. Go right to the RO. Thanks for your suggestion, Ready2Fight. I did make an appointment with a RO in 1-1/2 weeks (Early March) so I'm good there. The appointment secretary said that the doctor is out next week and wondered if i wanted to see someone else in the office and I said no I'll wait because I didn't think waiting 1-week longer would make much of a difference considering my relatively favorable pathology and relatively low PSA. But I'm still wondering if there is any benefit to having followup appointments for my surgery or if most folks just followup with their regular urologist? Tim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by joseywales Brothers, At my cancer conference I asked my doctor about activities or foods I should avoid. He said, "Don't worry about anything." I started doing a bit of reading and made an appointment with a nutritionist. I know diet is not going to cure my cancer, but if there are things that contributed to it it seems logical to slash them. Dairy and red meet seem like good candidates. I weighed in at 123lbs clothed. That's a little light for me. Body fat was estimated at 16.8 and BMI at 19.8 Here's what the nutritionist said: I'd like to get you up to 130 or 135 pre-treatment because you will lose some weight with any treatment. Let's try to add lean muscle Reduce cardio and increase weight training. Eat lean protein. Eat more fruits and vegetables. Drink plenty of water. Eat two eggs for breakfast. Eat legumes, but no more than 8oz per meal. Chicken and fish are good. Eat wild caught fish over farm raised. Have half a protein shake in the morning and half in the evening. Continue with B12 and multi-vitamins. Add D3 and probiotics. The goal is to consume 70-80g of protein per day. Whole grains are good. I asked about eggs, because I had heard some mixed things about them. She said they were good. I asked about sugar. "Sugar feeds cancer," she said. My uncle, who had throat cancer had already told me this and I thought it odd she did not bring it up. I asked about sugar in protein shakes. She said, "Get one with Stevia." So, here are my questions: I had heard that grains in general cause inflammation and inflammation is not good. What can you tell me about whole grains? It seems like if cancer loves sugar it would love stevia just as much. Am I incorrect in this hypothesis? I haven't had good luck finding much on eggs. MDA's website says they have gotten a bad rap but are good for you. I know they contain a lot of choline and had read something about choline being used in PET scans because it goes to the cancer. I did some reading. Even broccoli contains choline. What can you tell me about eggs? If anyone has any thoughts or recommendations, please let me know. Thanks! Josey "When things look bad, and it looks like you're not gonna make it, you've gotta get mean. I mean mad dog mean, because if you lose your head in a fight you neither win nor live. That's just the way it is." I have studied nutrition informally for many years due to my type 2 diabetes (and later PCa) and can give you my thoughts on the items above ... You asked about grains. Well, some grains may be OK if you don't have diabetes but grains in general turn into sugar and raise blood sugar so they could feed cancer and also cause inflamation. My personal opinion is that everyone would do better with less grains and diabetics should eliminate them alltogether (as I did). By the way, as a type 2 diabetic, removing grains was the best thing I ever did to lower my blood sugar. In the standard american diet, every american dish contains some grains usually and this is not necessary doing anyone any good. Stevia is OK because it does not raise blood sugar - it is a herb, not a sugar. Also check out Erythritol and to a lesser extent, xylitol - both of these are sugar alcohols which doesn't affect blood sugar much if at all but xylitol in particular and erythritol to a lesser extent could cause a laxitive effect if too much is eaten at a time. If you have a dog, I believe it is xylitol that you have to watch out for because it could be fatal to dogs since they can't digest it but the issue doesn't exist in humans. I used to bake cakes with only xylitol and they tasted just like sugar. Though cakes are problematic unless you can find a grain free cake which perhaps uses almond or some other grain-free flour rather than white grain-based flour. I can't weigh in on eggs because I don't like them so I may be biased if I do. But eggs are probably OK. There is some research that animal protein may affect Prostate Cancer but I think most if the problem centers around red meat. Much of the scientific literature on PCa and nutrition suggest a link to Red Meat and PCa. I would also recommend staying away from dairy as it could be problematic due to casein and cheese in particular is very addicting. Interestingly, for me I was eating Vegan from the time of diagnosis with PCa and my robotic surgery and between that 3 month period, my PSA didn't increase that fast, only a few tenths of a point as I recall. However, I started eating meat and probably more red meat than I should about a year after my surgery and my PSA is starting to climb (Not much but .02 in 3 months) and perhaps that would have been slowed if I had eaten Vegan instead. I don't however think anyone has to go vegan to do good with Prostate Cancer, I suspect it's a good idea to stay away from Red Meat or only eat it once or twice a month and the rest of the time, eat chicken or a vegan dish. Of all of the scientific literature I've looked at, I can't find anything bad said about poultry (Chicken, turkey, etc ...). In fact, I looked at a few studies recently that said there was no link between poultry consumption and PCa. Of there's definitely a benefit to adding more vegetables to your diet or eating some meals a week vegan and no meat at all. Nowadays, there are many vegan meat substitutes such as soybean pasta (Which I like) and bean pasta (also good if you can get over the black color). I would stay away anything with soy protein isolate or anything like that because it's highly processed and may have health consequences. There are also many recipes on the internet for vegan meat substitutes that you make from scratch - these are the best and most healthiest because you know what goes into them. Couple of other things you may want to look into - Consider adding tumeric root to some of your dishes, also fresh garlic and fresh ginger root, all Organic if possible. Also green tea (Like Matcha) is good too. All of these help decrease inflammation which could improve a cancer outcome. I want to mention I'm not a nutritionist but only a concerned citizen trying to improve my own health as much as possible and live as long as I can. Hope this helps - these are my personal opinions which could change over time if new research comes to light. Tim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ready2Fight For us our URO surgeon told us he didn't need to see us anymore. He said we could even just get our PSA tests through our family doctor. Once we had a slight rise on the uPSA that's when we connected with the RO. I was ordering the uPSA and paying out of pocket while we were with the URO surgeon. Once we started seeing the RO, she did give me the RX for the uPSA which was something the URO surgeon said he wasn't going to give me and he didn't want me seeking it out. During the year that his PSA was more or less "steady" while we were under the care of our RO and we thought things were going along somewhat uneventfully the plan was to either get an annual DRE from a local URO or our RO. We ended up getting the DRE from the RO. I suppose in hindsight, I should have sought out a RO right after surgery. But hoping my RO does what is necessary when I see him in about 12 days and if warranted, will expedite getting treatment started. Tim

Posts.Title: Next Step in SRT

Posts.Content: ktboston; Interestingly but unfortunately, I also ended up in the emergency room the very night I had my catheter removed. About midnight, I began experiencing back pain that was very strange in that I could never get comfortable and then that moved to being stomach pain. I don't like going to the emergency room because I don't think they're particularly helpful and I don't like all of those tests run on me but I got scared thinking maybe urine was leaking so I reluctantly drove myself to the nearest hospital emergency room since I live alone. Urine didn't show an infection. CT Scan was normal (so no I wasn't leaking urine) but one blood test that the doctor on call called a pancreas number was abnormal but she said that that can happen sometimes so she didn't feel any additional tests were necessary. I was actually feeling better by the time the doctor came back with the results so I went home. I have never experienced that issue again in nearly a year since my catheter removal and hopefully I never will. I'm assuming I got some sort of infection when the catheter was removed which quickly resolved itself (fortunately). I don't think I had a fever, though. Tim

Of course surgical technology improves all the time. Tim

Posts.Title: Single Incision RALP outpatient

Posts.Content: Hi All; So now it's been nine weeks since my surgery August 1st. I am still struggling with incontinence but it's getting better. Now I can lay down (awake) or sit in a chair without involuntary urination. I do experience involuntary urination sometimes when getting up from a seated position or standing but it's not nearly as much as it used to. I, however do experience urination at night while sleeping. It seems my "feeling" that I have to urinate isn't as great post surgery as it was pre surgery and near as I can tell, I am letting my bladder fill up during the night but not always getting enough sensation that it wakes me up. Sometimes I wake up after starting to urinate and other times I don't. I do want to mention that I have a few factors that are causing me to urinate more often during the night than most of you, namely type 2 diabetes and medication. Anyone have any thought or ideas about this and has anyone else experienced it ? It is annoying of course and I would like it to stop. I'm having to wash my clothes and bedsheets each day. I will discuss this with my surgeon at my 3 month followup next month to see if he has ideas about if this is normal or what to do about it. Tim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rmotacek1 I go to get my blood work done on June 8th and my urologist office scheduled me to get the results on June 29th. I don't think that I can wait that long. Anyone else think that is an unusually long wait to get results? Hi rmotacek1; Nowadays most labs at major hospitals allow you to sign up to get your lab results on-line so you can see them usually within 24 hours of the lab performing the test. In the worst case scenario, you can go and visit the lab and fill out a form to request your lab work and they should give it to you on the spot. If your lab work wasn't performed at a major hospital (For instance, a smaller, independent urology practice), you may need to contact the doctor's office. Tim

Posts.Title: PSA result wait time

Posts.Content: My first opinion urologist also suggested the possibility of active surveillance even though I had two 3+4 cores out of 12 - rest were 3+3. I later found out that I actually had a very small percentage of pattern 4 (5%) in each of the 3+4 cores. So probably waiting a bit would have been OK for me. However, I chose surgery not because it was one of the options, but because I just wanted the cancer out of me. I think with any amount of 3+4, I would chose surgery (as I did) because it will only grow and you'll eventually need treatment anyway. Better to have it done when you're younger and stronger and it's more curable. Just my opinion. Tim

Posts.Title: PSA result wait time

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Dog1967 I come seeking opinions on my post op pathology report. I'm sorry I don't know how to put it in my signature. Gleason Score 7 (98% pattern 3, 2% pattern 4) Tertiary Pattern not applicable Tumor 10% Extraprostatic Extension: Not involved Seminal Vesicle Invasion : Not Identified Margins: Involved by carcinoma Length of positive margin: 2 mm Location of margin: left mid Gleason pattern at margin: 3 Lympovascular Invasion: Not identified Primary tumor: pT2c so it seems I have good news except for the positive margin. How concerned should I be about the margin? Thanks for any input You had almost the same pathology report as me if you'll read my signature. I had a G3+4 but only a very small amount of 4. I also had a very small positive margin measuring 1mm whereas yours measured 2mm. If you look on a ruler, 1mm and 2mm are very small. Just like you, my gleason pattern at the positive margin is pattern 3 which is very slow growing. As some others suggested, discuss the implications of the positive margin with your uro surgeon but if I were you, I would feel pretty good about your overall pathology report. If you're curious, my URO surgeon said not to worry about my 1mm and yours will probably say the same thing about your 2mm. My URO surgeon told me he still thinks he cured me. Wishing you an undetectable PSA for as long as you live which I predict will be a very long time. Tim

Posts.Title: Need your advice/suggestions ...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Busby da Vinci scheduled for January 9. I've settled on Dr. Michael Mangelson because he did his residency at Mayo Clinic and he helped pioneer a new way of doing the operation that produces a better outcome for continence. I even asked him about doing kegel exercises in prep for surgery and he said don't bother. I've been doing them anyway. I've been through multiple hernia surgeries, both laparoscopic and open, and I know all about having a sore abdomen for several weeks. Back then the nurses instructed me on how to get up and down without using my abs which really helped. I just hope the da Vinci prostatectomy is not as bad as my hernia surgeries. I can't go through that again. I checked with my hernia surgeon and he told me not to worry about the previous surgeries and the mesh. He said the prostatectomy is on a completely different plane than the hernia surgeries. I have read a LOT of threads on the da Vinci prostatectomy on this forum and about what to expect. I have two concerns: 1) I don't own a recliner and 2) I'm going to have to take care of myself most of the time. I have some friends coming to stay with me but I am on my own when it comes to managing the catheter and bag. This concerns me. From what I have read here, I need to keep the catheter clean and keep an antibacterial and/or numbing (lidocaine) ointment on the catheter at the tip of the penis. That's my biggest fear, keeping things clean and lubricated without passing out at the sight of blood. One thing confuses me. In all that I have read on this forum I see a lot of comments saying the surgery did not cause a lot of pain and many people just used over the counter pain relievers. But some of those same people talked about how sore their abs were and it made it difficult to get up and down. So I'm wondering if I use the heavy duty pain pills, can I alleviate the abdominal soreness? I'm a wimp when it comes to pain. Hi Busby; I'm going to add my 2 cents here since I have gone through RP about a year and a half ago and I was in a similar situation as you. I also did not own a recliner and was concerned that that would be an issue for me PRIOR to RP but I found out for me, it wasn't necessary after returning home from the hospital. I did, however find it necessary to camp out on my comfportable sofa in the livingroom and sleeping there too. I didn't experience that much pain (Except from the catheter - more on that later) and I was able to get up off the sofa OK without assistance. I don't recall having a lot of sureness. I also didn't have anyone to help me since I live alone but I did ask a good friend to stop by once in a while and to run a few errands for me like get pills, etc  I really didn't end up needing her that much, though. One thing I did was to stsock up on food that I can reheat easily. If you are a good cook like I am, you could make a large quantity of meals and freeze them prior to surgery so you can just pop them in the microwave for the first few weeks following surgery. I wasn't permitted to drive before I got the cathether out which I believe was about 10 days so you should buy or prepare/freeze about 2 weeks worth of food. What everyone says about pain is correct - there really isn't much pain following surgery and for me, I didn't require that much pain medication. I did experience some gas pain about a day following surgery I think due to the a surgical procedure they do and for me it was annoying but it passed in a day or so and was gone before I left the hospital. The doctor wanted to discharge me from the hosp. the very next morning following surgery but I had to stay an extra day because that was the earliest my friend could pick me up. There was only one big issue I had upon arriving home. My catheter began burning extremely severely a few days after returning home - so much so that it was difficult to even walk without pain. Though I pretty much fault the hospital for this as the (male) nurse who gave me my homegoing instructions did not explain a thing about care and cleaning of the catheter. I'm assuming I was supposed to lubricate the end but they didn't say anything about that or give me any instructions. Once I got help and suggestions on this very forum  I was already in a lot of pain and it was too late and the day to get it removed couldn't come sooner. So be sure to ask your nursing staff if they need to give you any catheter instructions prior to being discharged. I know a lot of men on here report no pain and I'll bet that's because they probably lubricated the tip. A couple more things about the catheter. You will experience a red liquid in the catheter a day or two or perhaps a bit more following surgery but that is normal. Things eventually cleared up for me. Though starting a few days before I was to have my catheter removed, I started seeing some residue come through the catheter tubing and I called the nurse and she said that was normal. Also, fyi - I did not require any assistance taking care of changing the catheter bag by myself. It's very easy - you probably just turn a valve on the bag to empty the liquid (in the toilet, of course). Hope this helps. Tim

Posts.Title: My da Vinci date is January 9

Posts.Content: Thanks for all of your encouragement. Three years ago, my PSA was 2.9 and 2 months ago, it jumped to 5.9. I really don't know why (And I'm hitting myself for it now), why 2.9 didn't raise a red flag for me. Both doctor's who reviewed it didn't raise any concern. My internist doesn't order yearly psa tests for some reason and it just wasn't on my radar. I only had the psa test done three years ago because I got a physical from work and they automatically order them after age 50. I did not get a work physical in the two years thereafter but if I had, may have discovered a rising psa sooner. Regarding the nerve sparring stuff, I really don't understand any of that. However, he asked me my level of importance of three things and here's how I answered ... Most important was to get all of the cancer, second most important was to not have incontinence, and lowest priority was to not have ED. I know a lot would disagree with this order of priority but I have never been married and have never been sexually active so that is why I came to that decision. My largest concern is that he doesn what is necessary to live a normal lifespan. While I know a lot go through it, I am really fearful of high dose radiation as I believe it can lead to other cancer's. That's why I personally opted for surgery. Perhaps the doctor will eventually suggest radiation too after getting the final pathology report after surgery but hopefully not. I would feel better just to have the whole prostate removed. I have been eating an ultra healthy vegan diet for about the past 8 months (Long before I was diagnosed) along with fresh ginger, tumeric, and garlic every day and I expect that will help prevent a occurrence. I am thinking of getting a second opinion from MD Anderson. Since Prostate surgery is very serious, I would have no problem traveling a great distance to get better care I feel more comfortable with. Tim
Posts.Title: Newly Diagnossed - questions about choosing a surgeon

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by oshguy Hi, Your situation sounds very similar to mine, and I also elected surgery. Active surveillance was not recommended for me, not that I would have gone that route anyway. I wanted that cancerous thing out of my body permanently! While I could have had the surgery closer to home, my urologist recommended either Johns Hopkins or Cleveland Clinic. I'm located about equidistant from both, and elected to go to Cleveland. My surgeon was Dr. Andrew Stephenson, and he did a great job with both nerve bundles spared. I also live alone, and a friend agreed to accompany me to the hospital for the surgery and stay with me for a short while during recovery, which was completely uneventful. I usually think a second opinion is beneficial, though once I met with Dr. Stephenson I had complete confidence in him and didn't seek out any other opinions. I suspect I would have felt the same with a Johns Hopkins surgeon as well, knowing that they're among the best in the world. I think if I were in your position and so close to the Cleveland Clinic that I would at least get an opinion from a surgeon there. Good luck, and keep us posted with your progress through this process. Thanks, ohsguy. I just submitted a request for a second opinion at the Cleveland Clinic. I also checked out Dr. Stephenson's bio and video and he looks great plus your referral (The only one I have so far) clinched the deal so I requested him. Not sure if I'll get him though but hope I do and don't have to wait too long. Tim
Posts.Title: Newly Diagnossed - questions about choosing a surgeon

Posts.Content: Hello All; I'm 57 years old and I was diagnosed with prostate cancer about 3 weeks ago after getting a biopsy. My PSA was 5.9 a few months ago and my biopsy showed 6 cores positive with three a gleason 6 and three a gleason 7 (3+4). My urologist had me do a bone scan and mri and both were negative. What makes this harder is that I live alone and my mother passed away about 3 months ago. I do have two other brother's who I haven't told yet. Even though my urologist gave me the option of active surveillance, I didn't like the idea of waiting for the tumor to grow larger (which would cause me added stress) so I told my urologist that I wanted my prostate removed. He explained that this diagnosis was not a death sentence and a cure was possible. So he referred me to a robotic surgeon within his practice. I went to see the surgeon (Carson Wong) last week and while he seems like a competent surgeon (He said he did about 800 robotic surgeries when I asked him), I got the feeling like he rushed me through the appt. and didn't fully explain things. I was able to get a copy of the surgeon's notes and he stated "Given the patient's age, PSA value, volume of disease, and Gleason Score, curative therapy was recommended. Patient has elected to proceed with LEFT nerve sparing robotic-assisted laproscopic prostatectomy/BPLND)". Surgery is scheduled for the second week in July, I believe. Both urologist and surgeon seemed to say a cure was possible but when I asked the surgeon last week something regarding the potential for a cure, he said "there are no guarantees". So here are my questions ... 1. I see a lot of folks on this forum going to major hospitals to do surgery such as MD Anderson or Mayo Clinic. But is this really necessary and are good surgeons at other smaller community hospitals such as where I'm going (Southwest Urology/Parma Hospital)? My nearest major hospital in the area is Cleveland Clinic. 2. Since I have already selected surgery, is it worth getting a second opinion or seeking out a different surgeon who is friendlier who spends more time with you ? Thanks. Tim

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnossed - questions about choosing a surgeon

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rooster22 I read somewhere that teaching hospitals have students do some portion of surgery. That is how the students gain experience. Ask the surgeon if this is true, and if so, would you experience this. This is a very reasonable question to ask your surgeon. I, too am having my surgery done at a teaching hospital (Cleveland Clinic) in about 3 weeks (August 1st) so I actually asked my surgeon this in an email because I read that it is one of the questions you should ask. And he provided a very detailed answer. In fact, more detailed than I was expecting. He said he will be doing all of the surgery at the robot console. However, he did say that he has assistants that do non-critical things but I didn't get the impression that these are students. This only makes sense. He did say that he frequently has international visitors and medical students observing him in the operating room but they aren't doing any part of the surgery - they are only there to observe him (the surgeon) and learn from it. Since my surgery is scheduled for the summer (August 1st), I asked him about if summer students would also be present (I know the Cleveland Clinic hires a lot of summer students, btw) and he said that no summer interns will be present. Interestingly, my supervisor said that he was previously a Cleveland Clinic summer student and he actually was able to observe a Robotic Prostate Cancer Surgery but that was probably 15 years ago - not sure if that was an isolated case or if this is sometimes done. But I'm sure he was only there to observe. If it were me, I don't think I'd want to observe. This is another reason I asked the question. He did say that if I didn't want any international visitors/medical students observing, he will exclude them from my surgery. And I emailed him back and told him he need not exclude anyone - I was more interested in whether "HE" was doing the full surgery. Also when you think about it, if the surgeon has other doctor's observing his work, he and his associates must be confident in his abilities to let him do that. Tim

Posts.Title: Now I'm even more nervous

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by garyi Plus there is a bit more incentive for doing an excellent job, one would hope. I believe that, sometimes, residents or PA's will perform the open, insert the arms, grab the bagged prostate, and do the close. Good luck Tim! Thanks, garyi. Hmmm ... perhaps some surgeons allow this but not mine. From my surgeon's response, he said he's doing the full surgery. Here's an excerpt from the end of his response ... which made me feel really good ... "I do have senior level residents (5-6 years into their surgery training, 6-12 months from performing these operations independently) perform non-critical aspects of the surgery under my direct supervision. However, everything related to the prostate removal, nerve-sparing, reconstruction are done 100% by me.". I suppose it is possible that his senior-level residents perform the open, insert the arms, and do the close but these things are non-critical and if this worked for my surgeon's 700+ RP operations up to now, then I am OK with it. What happens when he's inside is really what counts and I would want him doing 100% of that which he said he does from the above response. It is still good to ask the surgeon this question especially if it bothers someone. I'll bet 99.9% of surgeons would be happy to answer and for the .1% that doesn't, I'd get another surgeon . Tim

Posts.Content: Hi All; I am planning to return to work. It has been just a few days over one month since my surgery on August 1st. I am a project manager and my job entails mostly sitting all day (at a computer) except an occasional walk to lunch or to a meeting. I am still not continent during the day. I am OK sitting down but once i get up, I start to urinate. I have tried kegel's prior to getting up but this doesn't stop the flow (yet). So for those of you who have had to return to work before being mostly continent, what did you do and how did you handle the situation so you didn't smell or become embarrassed ? I tried an external catheter but it didn't seem to work very well. Maybe I need to try a different brand. I ordered a penile clamp (to use only during working hours) to give that a try and it should arrive tomorrow. Tim

Posts.Title: Incontinence suggestions for returning to work after Prostate Surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by oshguy Hi, Your situation sounds very similar to mine, and I also elected surgery. Active surveillance was not recommended for me, not that I would have gone that route anyway. I wanted that cancerous thing out of my body permanently! While I could have had the surgery closer to home, my urologist recommended either Johns Hopkins or Cleveland Clinic. I'm located about equidistant from both, and elected to go to Cleveland. My surgeon was Dr. Andrew Stephenson, and he did a great job with both nerve bundles spared. I also live alone, and a friend agreed to accompany me to the hospital for the surgery and stay with me for a short while during recovery, which was completely uneventful. I usually think a second opinion is beneficial, though once I met with Dr. Stephenson I had complete confidence in him and didn't seek out any other opinions. I suspect I would have felt the same with a Johns Hopkins surgeon as well, knowing that they're among the best in the world. I think if I were in your position and so close to the Cleveland Clinic that I would at least get an opinion from a surgeon there. Good luck, and keep us posted with your progress through this process. Thanks, ohsguy. I just submitted a request for a second opinion at the Cleveland Clinic. I also checked out Dr. Stephenson's bio and video and he looks great plus your referral (The only one I have so far) clinched the deal so I requested him. Not sure if I'll get him though but hope I do and don't have to wait too long. Tim
Posts.Title: Newly Diagnossed - questions about choosing a surgeon

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee You may wish to read THIS THREAD from late last year. Lots of guys contributed to it. Personally I never had much luck with the clamp, or with pads for that matter. They didn't hold enough and my shaft had the tendency to flop off to one side or the other and miss the pad altogether. I came to rely primarily on external catheters and have written extensively on several different forums on the subject. My favorite, most comfortable and most reliable was the Freedom silicone with aloe, about $1.25 ea on Az, leg bag by Rusch about $2 ea also from Az. I would try to go a day or two each week w/o the CC and would use Prevail belted shields, which are also sold at CVS as their own brand. I think we discussed this in an earlier thread, so maybe you tried these and they did not work for you. Different strokes, as they say. Several ppl had suggested to me to place a pad inside a Depends brief, with only a small portion of the adhesive exposed. That way you can change the pad without changing the brief. I found it all to be way too bulky... but then I am slender and wear snug fitting trousers, so it definitely looked like I was wearing a diaper. Today I wear only a Tena moderate absorbent pad, the "3 drops" package. Hi Roblee; Correct ... you did mention earlier and I tried all of your suggestions ... see results below ... I did try the Freedom Silicon Catheter last week and it did work and I was able to collect urine in a leg bag but for some reason, it seemed to leak. I thought I measured the correct size but may measure again. They also seem to be available in limited sizes. There was another catheter that was recommended by someone else - may try that if I can find what it was. From what I'm reading, men seem to have variable success with the penile clamp - it seems as if most are able to use it but some have problems with it falling off. Maybe I will be one who has success. I did buy some belted shields - actually two packages of them - one locally and one off the internet and did try them and they seem to work though they didn't collect as much urine as a diaper did which makes sense. I did find them a bit difficult to button on but may revisit that. Would be nice if they had either velcro or snaps but I know that would increase the cost tremendously. Tim

Posts.Content: Hello TB; My first surgeon (Who I ended up not using) did a CT Scan of Pelvic area and Bone Scan (Because I had a Gleason Score of 3+4 - He said this would be a waste of money if I have had a 3+3). Then my second surgeon (Who I did end up using) ordered a 3T MRI of my Pelvic area during pre-surgical testing one week prior to surgery. I have not seen the results of that MRI but I assume this was to determine where the tumor was located to help with his surgery. I think both surgeons determined early on that my cancer had not spread due to my biopsy results, Gleason score, and Pre-surgical PSA. Tim

Posts.Title: Ensuring eligibility for surgery

Posts.Content: Sandra; First of all, can you tell us your dad's Gleason Score from his biopsy last year ? That will tell us on the forum how aggressive his cancer really is. And can you tell us as much as you can about what the doctor found from the biopsy such as the number of cores with cancer and how much in each core? If his doctor is able to make the diagnosis of "aggressive", he must be going by what he saw on the biopsy. Lots of biopsy results are being placed on-line these days but if not, insist that your dad's doctor provide is because he paid for it and is entitled to it. Secondly, I know a lot about natural treatments because I have been very interested in learning about the power of natural fruits and vegetables for many years. Before I get into this, you will find a lots of folks on YouTube and the internet that claim they cured cancer with homeopathic remedies. While I can't confirm or deny those claims, you really have to watch what you believe on youtube as I'm sure some (perhaps even most) of those folks fabricate those stories to make more money through advertising. OK so here are my recommendations ... 1. With a diagnosis as serious as prostate cancer, it will be of great benefit to your dad to supplement his conventional treatments with scientifically proven natural remedies. This is what I did and I believe it helped and is continuing to help. I was eating very healthy - an entirely vegetarian diet and a green smoothie (Broccoil, cabage, chia, hemp, and flax seeds, fresh turmeric root, fresh ginger root, etc ...) every morning. Then as you can see from my signature line at the bottom of this message, my PSA only climbed .2 in 6 months between diagnosis and surgery. 2. There are actually a lots of authorative medical studies and writings on the internet by prominent doctors which link certain elements of diet and lifestyle to better prostate cancer (and all cancer overall) outcomes. Here are a few to get you started ... https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/brady-urology-institute/specialties/conditions-and-treatments/prostate-cancer/prostate-cancer-questions/how-does-food-affect-prostate-cancer https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/brady-urology-institute/specialties/conditions-and-treatments/prostate-cancer/prostate-cancer-questions/exploring-the-link-between-evolution-and-prostate-cancer Also, There is some research that turmeric can improve prostate cancer outcomes. I am seeing a functional medicine doctor at the Cleveland Clinic and when she first heard I was just treated for Prostate Cancer, the first thing she mentioned was turmeric (Curcumin). And her claim is backed up by a research study ... https://www.hindawi.com/journals/bmri/2014/761608/. I know these are somewhat difficult to understand unless you're a doctor. Let us know if you can get your hands on some real data from your dad's biopsy and your forum friends will be better able to advise you. However, still keep in mind that none of us are doctors so we can only advise you based upon our personal experiences and what we hear (from our doctors) and read. I wish your dad the best of luck and I wish you the best of luck in convincing your dad that conventional medicine will give him the best outcome and longest life. At his age (69) his doctor will most likely recommend radiation, I believe. Though his doctor may ultimately leave it up to him. Tim

Posts.Title: Worried about my dad

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Three suggestions; stop all alcohol and caffeine. In addition to those three suggestions, when you get up from sitting contract the muscle first and clamp your penis with your hand. Full bowels also place pressure on the bladder. Keep them empty and preferably first thing in the morning. Restore your core muscles, do planks. Get your BMI between 19 and 24. All doable if you want it. Thanks Another; All great suggestions. Just thought I'd mention that I don't drink alcohol or caffeine. My BMI is 24.3 so very close to healthy. Sometimes I do clamp my penis with my hand and that does work but can't do that at work . Am trying a penile clamp for at work which should arrive today. I have been doing research on the internet and some doctor's suggest them and it seems as if lots of PCa patients use them. I'll have to keep that in mind regarding keeping my bowels empty. I do follow an extremly healthy lifestyle which includes eating lots of fiber so have one bowel movement atleast once a day. Though despite my healthy lifestyle, I am lacking in the Exercise department so I need to work on that. Great suggestion to exercise my core muscles. I hadn't thought about that. I am not sure what planks are so I'll have to google them as well as core exercises. Thanks so much for the great ideas. Tim

Posts.Content: I am experiencing pain in my left leg after robotic radical prostectomy. This is a dull pain that I notice more while I'm in bed and just getting up. It seems to have started in my thigh but then now moved to the lower left leg below my knee. It seems to minimize throughout the day when I'm walking around and active. I was concerned about a possible blood clot because I hear they're somewhat more common after a long surgery but I had my family doctor order a ultrasound of my left leg just to be sure and they did the test yesterday and the technician told me I do not have any blood clots. I know that the left leg is fairly close to the surgical area so wonder if the doc inadvertently disturbed a nerve or pulled a muscle. I plan to email the surgeon on Monday to let him know about this pain and seek suggestions about further testing if necessary. Anyone else experience anything like this after surgery ? I am now 2-1/2 weeks since surgery. Thanks. Tim

Posts.Title: Leg pain

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Three suggestions; stop all alcohol and caffeine. In addition to those three suggestions, when you get up from sitting contract the muscle first and clamp your penis with your hand. Full bowels also place pressure on the bladder. Keep them empty and preferably first thing in the morning. Restore your core muscles, do planks. Get your BMI between 19 and 24. All doable if you want it. Thanks Another; All great suggestions. Just thought I'd mention that I don't drink alcohol or caffeine. My BMI is 24.3 so very close to healthy. Sometimes I do clamp my penis with my hand and that does work but can't do that at work . Am trying a penile clamp for at work which should arrive today. I have been doing research on the internet and some doctor's suggest them and it seems as if lots of PCa patients use them. I'll have to keep that in mind regarding keeping my bowels empty. I do follow an extremly healthy lifestyle which includes eating lots of fiber so have one bowel movement atleast once a day. Though despite my healthy lifestyle, I am lacking in the Exercise department so I need to work on that. Great suggestion to exercise my core muscles. I hadn't thought about that. I am not sure what planks are so I'll have to google them as well as core exercises. Thanks so much for the great ideas. Tim

Posts.Title: Incontinence suggestions for returning to work after Prostate Surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee You may wish to read THIS THREAD from late last year. Lots of guys contributed to it. Personally I never had much luck with the clamp, or with pads for that matter. They didn't hold enough and my shaft had the tendency to flop off to one side or the other and miss the pad altogether. I came to rely primarily on external catheters and have written extensively on several different forums on the subject. My favorite, most comfortable and most reliable was the Freedom silicone with aloe, about $1.25 ea on Az, leg bag by Rusch about $2 ea also from Az. I would try to go a day or two each week w/o the CC and would use Prevail belted shields, which are also sold at CVS as their own brand. I think we discussed this in an earlier thread, so maybe you tried these and they did not work for you. Different strokes, as they say. Several ppl had suggested to me to place a pad inside a Depends brief, with only a small portion of the adhesive exposed. That way you can change the pad without changing the brief. I found it all to be way too bulky... but then I am slender and wear snug fitting trousers, so it definitely looked like I was wearing a diaper. Today I wear only a Tena moderate absorbent pad, the "3 drops" package. Hi Roblee; Correct ... you did mention earlier and I tried all of your suggestions ... see results below ... I did try the Freedom Silicon Catheter last week and it did work and I was able to collect urine in a leg bag but for some reason, it seemed to leak. I thought I measured the correct size but may measure again. They also seem to be available in limited sizes. There was another catheter that was recommended by someone else - may try that if I can find what it was. From what I'm reading, men seem to have variable success with the penile clamp - it seems as if most are able to use it but some have problems with it falling off. Maybe I will be one who has success. I did buy some belted shields - actually two packages of them - one locally and one off the internet and did try them and they seem to work though they didn't collect as much urine as a diaper did which makes sense. I did find them a bit difficult to button on but may revisit that. Would be nice if they had either velcro or snaps but I know that would increase the cost tremendously. Tim

Posts.Title: Incontinence suggestions for returning to work after Prostate Surgery

Posts.Content: I am experiencing pain in my left leg after robotic radical prostectomy. This is a dull pain that I notice more while I'm in bed and just getting up. It seems to have started in my thigh but then now moved to the lower left leg below my knee. It seems to minimize throughout the day when I'm walking around and active. I was concerned about a possible blood clot because I hear they're somewhat more common after a long surgery but I had my family doctor order a ultrasound of my left leg just to be sure and they did the test yesterday and the technician told me I do not have any blood clots. I know that the left leg is fairly close to the surgical area so wonder if the doc inadvertently disturbed a nerve or pulled a muscle. I plan to email the surgeon on Monday to let him know about this pain and seek suggestions about further testing if necessary. Anyone else experience anything like this after surgery ? I am now 2-1/2 weeks since surgery. Thanks. Tim

Posts.Title: Leg pain

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider Rating surgeons based on results can be problematic I think. The top men often get the most difficult and challenging assignments, the ones where a good result isn't always possible, at least compared to easier or more typical situations. I think that's the real challenge here, making sure you are not comparing apples to oranges. I actually discovered this site after selecting my surgeon, Dr. Andrew Stephenson at the Cleveland Clinic who got only one star. It initially stressed me out but then after reading a few reviews about this site, I agree with Southsider. I still think it's a good decision to go with anyone at the Cleveland Clinic which has been rated 2nd in Urology and 7th in cancer. Since this was my 2nd opinion, I'm don't think I'm going to seek a third opinion with 5 stars (Thus delaying surgery further) solely on the basis of a review. He has done 700+ robotic prostate cancer surgeries averaging about 4 a week. I also looked at all of the surgeons in my area and only a few got 5 stars and most got 3 stars and a few got 1 star. I'm not so sure that 1 star vs. 3 stars is that big a difference anyway. With a Gleason 7 (3+4) on a 1st and 2nd opinion biopsy with only 5% G4 in two cores, I am hoping that my case won't be that difficult and that my final pathology will remain Gleason 7 (3+4) or better. Tim

Posts.Content: I received a response from my surgeon today. His nurse answered it and responded ... "This PSA will still collect data and whether the result is detectable or not which is what the doctor is looking for." This is correct because my pre-surgery Free PSA test also included PSA as well (two tests). I will question him about this at my 3-month post-op followup to find out his rationale for ordering the Free PSA test rather than a PSA test alone and let him know my concerns about added cost. I am also wondering why he didn't order an ultrasensitive PSA test that lots of you seem to be getting. Tim

Posts.Title: Question about PSA test following RP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Duck2 http://riskcalc.org/ProstateCancerPr...Prostatectomy/ Clueless on the third field Capusalar Invasion Type. Hmmm ... I found your question interesting. I had RP at the Cleveland Clinic, and I see my surgeon was one of the authors of that calculator. I had a very small positive margin of 1mm on my final pathology and the following statement is noted on my pathology report ... "Extraprostatic Extension: Cannot be determined: Tumor is present at the inked margin of resection in an area of capsular incision " What this tells me is that possibly my cancer was close to the edge of the prostate capsule and my surgeon must have cut into the cancer by a very tiny amount, leaving a tiny amount behind. I have a feeling when sparring the nerves that it's difficult to tell exactly where the exact edge of the prostate is. Maybe capsular invasion and capsular incision mean the same things and maybe its a CCF thing since I haven't ever heard of it mentioned in any other pathology report reported on here. I believe focal means at one spot and mine was in only one spot. Looks like I could be on my way to BCR and Radiation as a result of this. However, I am puzzled why the calculator also has a question about a positive margin as I would think a capsular invasion would be a positive margin. You could ask your doctor about this at a followup visit. I may ask mine as well. Tim

Posts.Title: Help for Newly Diagnosed D2 Prostate Cancer with Bone Mets

Posts.Content: Hello All; My Robotic Prostatectomy is in only two days (August 1st) and I have some questions ... I am feeling pretty hopeful with a Gleason 3+4 and only 5% of patttern 4 in each of two 3+4 cores. Additionally, now seeing my pre-surgery PSA rise only .2 in 6 months makes me feel even more confident that I have a slow growing disease. 1. It seems as if a lot of men suffer from Bladder Spasm's due to having their catheter in. And some describe them as a constant urge to urinate and others describe it as an excruciating pain. I am curious how often this happens and how much of a problem this was for you? Be honest here. Also, if this did happen to you, did you find anything that brought them on and anything that minimized or eliminated them ? 2. What will my diet be like following surgery and how long will it take to improve? I believe it is recommended to have a liquid diet following surgery but I am curious why this is, and how soon (days?) generally until I could have solid food ? 3. Am curious how long your hospital stay was and if there were any complications in your case ? I was told by a nurse 2-3 days but most everywhere I read seems to indicate only overnight. 4. It seems the general advice is to sleep on a recliner rather than a bed following Robotic Prostatectomy. I am curious why this is and what is the actual thing that makes sleeping in a bed difficult ? Reason I ask is because I don't have a recliner. For those of you who didn't have a recliner, how did you manage sleeping ? Also, how long does it take (Days?) until you were able to sleep on a regular bed ? 5. When you returned home from the hospital, is there anything that you absolutely couldn't do by yourself and needed help with ? Reason I ask is because I live alone but can have a friend stop over once in a while. 6. What did you take to the hospital on your surgery day ? Thanks. Tim

Posts.Title: Robotic prostatectomy in two days - Some questions

Posts.Content: Congratulations, Dave. Great to hear things went smoothly for you and happy to hear you are finished. I have begun seeling a RO a few weeks ago and he's monitoring my PSA monthly. My PSA hasn't increased beyond .05 in 4 months and in the last 3 weeks it stayed .05 so I'm guessing he won't want to start radiation when I see him next Tuesday until I see a rise beyond .05. My RO said I didn't need HT given the large number of side effects. I assume he thought that the benefits didn't outweigh the side effects given my pathology. He did say there was a new pill coming out that I could try as an alternative to HT which doesn't have all of the side effects. I didn't think to ask if this was a clinical trial or an already-approved drug. If it gets to that, I'll find out. I'll ask my Urologist to weigh in on whether HT would have any benefit for me as well. Tim

Posts.Content: zaldamo; So sorry to hear about your stepdad. Since you're considering the Cleveland Clinic as one possible hospital, I'll mention that I went there and had a pretty good outcome though my cancer was still confined to the prostate with a very tiny positive margin. Posts.Title: Help for Newly Diagnosed D2 Prostate Cancer with Bone Mets

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DavefromMD Wow, I feel so fortunate. My urologist automatically sent them to Hopkins for a second opinion. Yeah ... but is your doctor part of a medical practice that also does surgery? That was my case and they try to steer you in the direction of having it done by them because that's profits for them. I wish my urologist would have immediately sent me to the Cleveland clinic first as that would have saved a few weeks. I'm leaving work early today to talk to my urologist this afternoon to cancel their surgery and arrange to have them send the biopsy slides to my new Cleveland Clinic Surgeon. Tim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Tim! Just want to add 1 point: You should have received a copy of your Bx path report. Be sure to get a copy and keep it in your records. Do the same with your post RP Path Report and all future PSA lab reports. Good luck! The CC is a phenomenal place! MF Thanks for the tips. I already have a copy of the biopsy report and will be sure to get and keep a copy of the final pathology report following surgery and all future PSA tests. Thanks for your endorsement of the Cleveland Clinic. I only wish I didn't have to wait 2 months for surgery - hopefully I'll get lucky and there will be a cancellation. I hate to have something continuing to grow inside of me. Tim

Posts.Content: Hi all; Thanks so much for your quick response. I actually already talked to the lab that was listed on the biopsy report. They said they sent the slides back to the original requesting doctor. Did this ever happen to any of you ? From what I could gather (but I could still be wrong), the doctor does the biopsy and then prepares the slides. Then they send them to another company for analysis and then this other company sends them back. Does this sound right? So it sounds like I will need to go to my original doctor to have them forward these slides on to the new doctor. I should be on good terms of course when he finds out I didn't use his organization to do the surgery, he may no longer be on good terms. However, if he's a nice doctor (as I believe him to be), he shouldn't care if I go somewhere else. Plus, I did pay for them. So I should own them. Hmmm ... maybe I better check to be sure I paid that bill, ha ha ha. Tim

Posts.Content: Hello All; My Robotic Prostatectomy is in only two days (August 1st) and I have some questions ... I am feeling pretty hopeful with a Gleason 3+4 and only 5% of patttern 4 in each of two 3+4 cores. Additionally, now seeing my pre-surgery PSA rise only .2 in 6 months makes me feel even more confident that I have a slow growing disease. 1. It seems as if a lot of men suffer from Bladder Spasm's due to having their catheter in. And some describe them as a constant urge to urinate and others describe it as an excruciating pain. I am curious how often this happens and how much of a problem this was for you? Be honest here. Also, if this did happen to you, did you find anything that brought them on and anything that minimized or eliminated them ? 2. What will my diet be like following surgery and how long will it take to improve? I believe it is recommended to have a liquid diet following surgery but I am curious why this is, and how soon (days?) generally until I could have solid food ? 3. Am curious how long your hospital stay was and if there were any complications in your case ? I was told by a nurse 2-3 days but most everywhere I read seems to indicate only overnight. 4. It seems the general advice is to sleep on a recliner rather than a bed following Robotic Prostatectomy. I am curious why this is and what is the actual thing that makes sleeping in a bed difficult ? Reason I ask is because I don't have a recliner. For those of you who didn't have a recliner, how did you manage sleeping ? Also, how long does it take (Days?) until you were able to sleep on a regular bed ? 5. When you returned home from the hospital, is there anything that you absolutely couldn't do by yourself and needed help with ? Reason I ask is because I live alone but can have a friend stop over once in a while. 6. What did you take to the hospital on your surgery day ? Thanks. Tim

Posts.Title: Where will you be for the eclipse?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gwinkler Hello everyone, I am 43 years old and was put on testosterone therapy(injections 200ml biweekly) after a month of use I started having urinary problems. Went to my GP and he did a DRE and found a nodule on the left side of my prostate. My PSA 3 months ago was 1.0. He sent me to a Urologist which has set me up for CT scan tomorrow of my pelvis. He has scheduled me also for biopsy and a cysto on 9/11/17. I've of course have stopped the testosterone immediately! I'm so worried and don't know if my mind is playing tricks on me, but I started having back pain. Any advise or knowledge you can pass my way would be helpful.. Thank you all!! Hi gwinkler; I can attest that our mind is a very powerful thing and it is possible to make pain in any body part that you fixate on. I think as you fixate on a particular area such as your back, you are more aware of pains that originate there and of course you think the worst. I tend to worry about a lots of things and when I worry about a brain tumor, I get small pains in my head, and the same goes for when I was diagnosed with prostate cancer - I began thinking that my pelvic lymph nodes hurt because they were enlarged but later found that they were perfectly normal. At your age, Prostate Cancer is very rare. But consider this a learning experience and begin getting your PSA tested every year after 45, or 50. Many doctor' don't believe in PSA tests so you may need to specifically request it and don't accept NO for an answer. If you are concerned about PCa, you should let your general doctor know (or a urologist if you're seeing one). So ... keep your doctor's informed of your worries and symptoms but you probably don't have prostate cancer at this young age. Tim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Khendo14 Update on my surgery: Robotic Radical Prostectomy on 8/9. No lymph nodes taken, nerve sparing, one seminal vessels taken. Foley was taken out on day 6. 100% full bladder control since removal, and no issues since returning home. I have been experiencing pain just below my hips and down into my legs. I believe it is restless leg syndrome. Does anyone have any experience with this? My surgeon expects a full recovering as all margins were negative. Very thankful for the support from this forum. I had my surgery nine days before you (August 1, 2017). Good to see things turned out well for you. Interestingly, I also experienced pain in my left hip and down my left leg. I was so paranoid that I had a blood clot (because they are more common in abdominal surgeries) that I had my family doctor order a ultrasound of my left leg but it was negative. So I think what you experienced is likely normal and perhaps maybe due to the unusual position they had you in during the surgery. The pain is pretty much gone now but once in a while I still experience some pain in my left leg like while sleeping. But it hardly never happens - think it's just the position I'm in. Tim Tim

I just had mine removed today (Thank Goodness) and for the past 5 days it was so painful (Burning pain continuously and sharper burning pain when moving and bending) I consider it a Major pain in the butt and would have screamed and yelled if they would have told me to keep it in another week. Posts.Title: Cursed catheter!

Posts.Content: Hello All; I thought I'd update you since I have just passed the 3 month mark following surgery. First, I'll say that I am feeling great. I had my second post-surgery PSA test yesterday and it was the same as at 6 weeks or <.03. So I'm feeling good about that. I have a 3-month followup with my surgeon next Wednesday. The only big issue I'm still dealing with is incontinence. Though I feel it is getting better. Basically, my status is this ... During the day, my incontinence isn't bad and I am able to get through the day with only one belted shield. However, during the night, I still seem to wet the bed though I'm not sure why. I have taken some of this discomfort out by using the uro-dry condom catheter only during the night but it still tends to leak a little but not nearly as much as without it. My urge to urinate post surgery has never been as great as it was pre-surgery. Maybe that has something to do with it. I do seem to get up when my bladder is full but I still seem to find myself wet most of the time. I do tend to drink liquids and eat fruit later into the evening and while that never caused a problem pre-surgery, maybe it is causing a problem now. Need to experiment with stopping fluids at 6 PM or 7 PM to see if that has any effect. I will discuss my incontinence status with my surgeon on Wednesday to see if he has any suggestions. Tim

Posts.Title: 3 months following surgery - update

Posts.Content: Hi All; Here's another update. I had my 3 month followup with my surgeon last Wednesday. He didn't really tell me anything but I told him a lot. I expressed concern over my incontinence issues and also bedwetting. He did not seem overly concerned about both and said that at only 3 months from surgery, I should give it more time. He did schedule physical therapy which I requested so I start that in about a month. He said it's really important I continue Kegel Exercises. I also explained that my frequency of urination at night was about once every 2 hours same as pre-surgery and I expected that to get better after removing prostate but it did not. He said there is nothing wrong with my bladder and frequency of urination too should improve with time - this is a comment that surprised me but also encouraged me. I would absolutely love to be able to sleep throughout the whole night and if I am able to someday soon, that will be the second biggest benefit to me (besides getting rid of cancer) of having Prostate surgery. I did sleep without a catheter this past week and the quantity of urine I expel during the night seems to have reduced quite a bit so I am confident in time, this issue will go away too. My surgeon scheduled my next PSA test for 6 months and I was a bit surprised it wasn't 3 months. However, I suppose he based that frequency on my medical history and final pathology. Tim

Posts.Title: 3 months following surgery - update

Posts.Content: I got my catheter out just a month ago for an August 1st, 2017 surgery. While I don't think my urine was the color of blood, it was definitely dark(er) than one would expect so it could very well have had blood mixed with urine in it. It seemed to get lighter-colored as I progressed through the week. I also noticed some clots coming through the tube and was afraid that these could cause some pain after the catheter came out but they never did. I did call the nurse and ask about these clots and she said that was normal. If you're concerned, it is advisable to ask your doctor but since the bladder took major trauma, it seems to make sense it could start bleeding. Tim

I also noticed some clots coming through the tube and was afraid that these could cause some pain after the catheter came out but they never did. I did call the nurse and ask about these clots and she said that was normal. If you're concerned, it is advisable to ask your doctor but since the bladder took major trauma, it seems to make sense it could start bleeding. Tim

Posts.Title: Recovering now from my surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by sudds63 Hello, Final Report, Prostrate Radical Prostatectomy: Prostatic Adenocarcinoma , poorly differentiated Gleason Score of 4+5=9 (grade 5) Dominant Nodule with a Greatest dimension of 2.4 cm confined within prostate Estimated at 29% of tissue volume (7.14ml) involving surgical resection margins( anterior, at apex); benign seminal vesicles positive for perineral invasions: negative for invasion angiolymphatic invasion no lymph node identified. (NGPIN) High-grade Prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia. Well here it is from my biopsy I was told of Gleason score of 4+3=7 and the final is a 9. The doctor told me that I need 8 to 10 weeks of radiation now because it a more aggressive cancer then thought and I have to get my first post psa test at the end of the mth and that is will determine the amount of weeks I go. He also said its a good thing I got this done now then if I was to wait. I'm worried. I also got so sick after my catheter was removed I got a bad uti with high fever and had catheter put back in for another 8 days because I couldn't pee. Has not been a good week. Also the same week my hot water heater blew and our dog died of cancer, then I got my path report.... Well that's enough thanks for listening. Sudds Sudds; Sorry to hear about the negative pathology report though after radiation, you may still be cured. Interestingly, I got sick the day I had my catheter removed - Not the way you did, but late at night on the day I got my catheter removed, my back started hurting and I couldn't sleep because I couldn't get comfortable ... then the issue seemed to migrate to stomach with extreme pain. It was so bad I decided to check myself into the emergency room at about 3 am. Doc did a CT scan and blood tests and determined that my CT was fine but my pancreas number was higher than normal which the doc said she sees from time to time. She sent me home and the pain finally started to subside. It's now been almost 2 months since that fateful day and the problem never returned (fortunately) so I think it was related in some way to my surgery or catheter removal. Tim
