Posts.Title: Got my Path final report back, not good

Posts.Content: Hello All; Just thought I'd mention that a doctor from the Cleveland Clinic called today about my two consecutive PSA rises and advised me to make an appointment with a radiation oncologist. I'm really impressed that an actual doctor called and not just a nurse or appointment secretary. He said my PSA isn't rising that fast and he also noted that it was over a year post RP that it started rising so I took these to be good signs. I asked him about my surgeon and he wouldn't give me any details - said he just left the clinic suddenly. I hope nothing bad happened to him like an accident or nervous breakdown. But the big thing I told him when he suggested I make an appointment with a Radiation Oncologist is that I was one step ahead of him and already did ... for next Monday. I also asked him for a few excellent urologist recommendations for followup care as an alternative for my current Nurse Practicioner recommendation and he gave me several. One stuck in my mind so I will likely make an appointment eventually, depending upon what my radiation oncologist says and if or when we will start radiation. Tim

Posts.Title: Need lots of advice - PSA rising - results I didn't want to see

Posts.Content: Hello All; Looks like I'm heading for salvage radiation. My PSA 3 months ago was .03 and yesterday it is .05. I had surgery by a doctor at the Cleveland Clinic but that doctor apparently left the clinic a few months ago and now I can't even message him. They made me a followup appointment with a Certified Nurse Practitioner for 3 months from now and I can't even message her to have questions answered because apparently you can only message doctors through Mychart. How do I find a Radiation Oncologist ? Are there world class radiation oncologists like there are world class doctors? How do I find one? Should I receive treatment at the Cleveland Clinic or should I travel somewhere ? I really want to do something as soon as possible because .03 to .05 is quite a big jump. If I wait even 3 months, it may jump to .07. Tim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by garyi I assume your CC is the Ohio one. They aren't living up to their sterling reputation. Djin is giving you good advise. I wouldn't be in such a hurry to rush into SRT at your relatively low PSA. Give it some time to settle, and find another RO soon. Thanks or both of your advice, garyi, and Djin and the other folks who offered suggestions too. Yes, garyi - CC is supposed to be #1 in urology, and #5 in cancer. I think my surgeon did pretty good since there were no complications of the actual surgery and he can't see microscopic cancer cells that could escape. Based upon my extensive research and reading some folks BCR even from hospitals more respected than the Cleveland Clinic and even without positive margins. Well I made an appointment with a RO for early in March at a Cleveland Clinic facility near me. I'll see what he suggests. I think I'll ask for monthly ultra sensitive PSA tests just to keep tabs on what my PSA is doing more closely. I am nervous because I want to knock out any remaining cancer cells before they get out of hand. I probably should get a second opinion too from another RO too, perhaps not from the Cleveland Clinic. There are several other pretty good hospitals near me. I see some folks pulling the trigger on SRT at ridiculously low PSA values like .018 providing they see a trend upward. While I've passed .02, I'm willing to pull the trigger too if I see a clear trend upward too after beginning monthly PSA tests. But I'm also anxious to hear what the RO thinks too. I was hoping to delay SRT until I retire next year but that may not be possible to wait that long. Tim

Posts.Title: Half Way Through SRT

Posts.Content: redbelly7; The following study (below) demonstrates the benefits of consuming pomegranate juice to slow the progression of Prostate Cancer. Drinking Pomegranate juice is an easy step to take as it could be substituted for your morning orange juice or coffee and it won't hurt but may help. I prefer to juice whole fruit in a vitamix rather than buying juice in a bottle because I'm sure some of the nutrition is lost in the processing and bottling process. Below is an excerpt from the study ... "The most striking evidence for the biological activity of pomegranate extracts was demonstrated in prostate cancer cells. In vivo and in vitro studies have shown that pomegranate extracts are capable of inhibiting tumor cell proliferation, migration, and invasion, while also inducing apoptosis." If you want to read the full article, the link is below ... https://www.hindawi.com/journals/ecam/2013/701434/ Tim

Posts.Content: Hello All; I just got back from the doc's office today and had my doc explain my pathology report but he didn't take too long explaining things. He said my cancer was likely cured. Wonder if anyone can shed some light on your overall impression of the report ... It's pretty detailed and I listed the full report below but I noticed a few things in the report ... 1. Stage PT2: Organ Confined 2. But it also lists a very small positive margin (1mm) which the doctor wasn't too concerned with. Why? 3. Gleason pattern at positive margin - Pattern 3. Full report below ... FINAL DIAGNOSIS 1. Preprostatic fat, excision (A) - Fibromuscular and adipose tissue negative for tumor. 2. Prostatic radical prostatectomy (B) - Adenocarcinoma of the prostate, Gleason score 3+4=7 (Grade Group 2). See synoptic report. - Benign prostatic hyperplasia, glandular and stromal types. - Seminal vesicles are negative for tumor. - Margin of resection is focally positive for tumor. 3. Pelvic lymph node part A, excision (C) - One lymph node, negative for tumor (0/1). 4. Pelvic lymph node part B, excision (D) - Three lymph nodes, negative for tumor (0/3). CMG/kr 08/04/2017 SYNOPTIC REPORT OF KEY PATHOLOGIC FINDINGS PROSTATE: PROSTATE GLAND: RADICAL PROSTATECTOMY Specimen Site: Prostatic structure Tumor Site: Prost ate Areas of involvement: Right posterolateral and posterior apical-mid peripheral zone Principal area of involvement: Right posterolateral and posterior apical-mid peripheral zone Focality: Single nodule Proportion (percentage) of prostate involved by tumor: 10% Procedure: Radical prostatectomy with pelvic lymph node dissection Prostate Size: Size: 5.5cm Size: 4.0cm Size: 4.5cm Prostate Weight: Weight: 69.8 g without seminal vesicle Lymph Node Sampling: Pelvic lymph node dissection Histologic Type: Adenocarcinoma (acinar, not otherwise specified) Primary Gleason Pattern 3 Secondary Gleason Pattern 4 Tertiary Pattern not applicable Total Gleason Score: 7 % of 4 and/or 5: 1-10% % of 3: 91--100% New Grading System: Gleason score 3+4=7: Grade Group 2 Intraductal carcinoma: Intraductal carcinoma not identified Tumor Quantitation: Percentage o f prostate involved by tumor: 10% Tumor size (dominant nodule): Greatest dimension: 20 mm Extraprostatic Extension: Cannot be determined: Tumor is present at the inked margin of resection in an area of capsular incision Urinary Bladder Neck Invasion (Microscopic): Urinary bladder neck invasion microscopic not identified Seminal Vesicle Invasion: Not identified Margins: Margin(s) involved by invasive carcinoma: limited (<3 mm) Linear length of positive margin(s): 1 mm Postero-lateral (neurovascular bundle) margin(s) involved by invasive carcinoma: Right Gleason pattern at positive margin, Pattern 3 Treatment Effect on Carcinoma: Not identified Lymphovascular Invasion: Not identified Pathologic Stage Classification (pTNM, AJCC 7th Edition) TNM Descriptors: Not applicable Primary Tumor (pT): pT2: Organ confined Regional Lymph Nodes (pN): pN0: No positive regional nodes Number of regional lymph nodes examined: 4 Number of regional lymph nodes involved - none identified Distant Metastasis (pM): Not applicable Additional Pathologic Findings: Nodular prostatic hyperplasia Representative Tumor Block: Specify: B16, B13, B11

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another If I had a recurrence the only fact I think I'd want from the surgeon is where did anyting look suspicious to direct the next round of treatment. Unless they made notes I can't imagine they'd remember or even want the responsibility of sharing information like that. I've heard of surgeons sometimes placing clips to mark a spot. Other than that, it's on to the next expert. I was reading this thread and your comment about the "surgeon taking notes" jumped out at me. After my surgery at the Cleveland Clinic, I specifically asked if my surgeon took notes and indeed he did - all three typed pages of them providing a highly detailed explanation of exactly what he did through the entire RP procedure. I couldn't imagine him typing while he was cutting so I'm guessing he spoke them to someone else to type. Maybe all surgeons keep detailed notes on every procedure they do, perhaps now even more to protect themselves from a lawsuit. Dave From MD, you may ask Partin's office he he took notes during your procedure. I would expect any surgeon would be happy to give a patient their notes, especially if they're proud of their work. My surgeon didn't hesitate giving me his notes when I asked for them which I'll take as a sign he was proud of his work . I do want to warn that it's a little strange reading about the procedure that was done on you, but it's also informative. Of course, my doctor and probably yours too used a ton of strange names that you have no idea what they mean unless you google them. I will make another comment. Not sure if Hopkins is different but my surgeon is happy to see me for followup care. I've had two followup visits post-rp and at my 1 year anniversary I see him once a year with quarterly PSA tests. Though perhaps after 5 years of undetectable (fingers crossed) he'll taper off my visits. I wish you the very best of success moving forward, Dave from md. Tim

Posts.Title: Surgery at Hopkins - Post Surgical Interactions?

Posts.Content: Hi lostsoul65; I have been interested in nutritional benefits of food and supplements for many years before I was diagnosed with PCa. Have studied a lot and looked at a ton of research studies linking food to health benefits. Saw Palmetto is suspected of having benefit to prostate health. However, I have never heard of it being used as a benefit to prostate cancer. I tried it for a while it didn't seem to make my prostate issues go away or reduce prior to having my prostate removed. Of course, when the prostate is removed, Saw Palmetto has no benefit to prostate health. For overall health, you may want to look at eating a healthful diet - less sugar and carbs, more vegetables, and healthy fat. Also, it is far, far better to get your nutrition from food than it is from any supplements. Plus, Supplements are very, very expensive. One of my daily rituals in the morning is to blend a bunch of broccoli and cabbage with a tablespoon each of chia seeds, hemp seeds, flax seeds, and pumpkin seeds along with a small piece of fresh turmeric root (Which you can get at health food stores and some grocery stores). This is my breakfast. This is a Prostate Cancer forum so I'll mention there have been a few studies and some articles written by well-known medical facilities linking a healthful diet to preventing or improving the outcomes of existing prostate cancer. I posted a few of them and you can find them by searching on my name. You do not specify if you are affected by Prostate Cancer. If not (And we on this forum are hoping not), you can use this information in an attempt to prevent it from affecting you in the future. Tim

Posts.Content: Hi All; If you'll recall, I was diagnosed with Prostate Cancer about a month ago and went to one surgeon but didn't like him so I sought a second opinion from the world famous Cleveland Clinic. I decided to go with the CC but they wanted to confirm the biopsy results with their own pathologist as a condition of doing the surgery. Well, I got the Biopsy results back today from the CC and to me, they look good but maybe some of you can chime in too. Looks like my Gleason number didn't change (Yay !!!) - it is still a 7 (3 + 4). Also, this new biopsy did something the other biopsy didn't - it specified the percentage of Gleason 4 in the (3+4) tumors and both are only 5% which to me seems good. I'll bet if I would have had a biopsy a year ago, the pattern 4 wouldn't have even been there. Of course even better news would be that those 3+4's turned into 3+3's but no such luck. Now the last thing to stress about is the final pathology after surgery at the Cleveland Clinic but hopefully it will remain 3+4 (or better). Actual results are below ... FINAL DIAGNOSIS 1. Prostate, left lateral base, needle biopsy (THS17-1380 A, 05/01/2017) - Benign prostatic tissue. - Portion of benign seminal vesicle/ejaculatory duct tissue. 2. Prostate, left lateral mid, needle biopsy (THS17-1380 B) - Adenocarcinoma of the prostate, Gleason score 3+3=6 (Grade Group 1), discontinuously involving 45% of one of one core and measuring 6 mm. 3. Prostate, left lateral apex, needle biopsy (THS17-1380 C) - Benign prostatic tissue. 4. Prostate, left base, needle biopsy (THS17-1380 D) - Benign prostatic tissue. 5. Prostate, left mid, needle biopsy (THS17-1380 E) - Benign prostatic tissue. 6. Prostate, left apex, needle biopsy (THS17-1380 F) - Benign prostatic tissue. 7. Prostate, right base, needle biopsy (THS17-1380 G) - Adenocarcinoma of the prostate, Gleason s core 3+4=7 (Grade Group 2), discontinuously involving 70% of one of one core and measuring 11 mm. - Gleason pattern 4 comprises approximately 5% of the tumor. - Cribriform pattern 4 is not identified. 8. Prostate, right mid, needle biopsy (THS17-1380 H) - Prostatic tissue with small focus of atypical glands. 9. Prostate, right apex, needle biopsy (THS17-1380 I) - Benign prostatic tissue. 10. Prostate, right lateral base, needle biopsy (THS17-1380 J) - Adenocarcinoma of the prostate, Gleason score 3+4=7 (Grade Group 2), discontinuously involving 40% of one of one core and measuring 4.5 mm. - Gleason pattern 4 comprises approximately 5% of the tumor. - Cribriform pattern 4 is not identified. - Perineural invasion is present. 11. Prostate, right lateral mid, needle biopsy (THS17-1380 K) - Adenocarcinoma of the prostate, Gleason score 3+3=6 (Grade Group 1), involving 15% of one of one core and measuring 1.5 mm. 12. Prostate, right lateral apex, needle biopsy (THS 17-1380 L) - Adenocarcinoma of the prostate, Gleason score 3+3=6 (Grade Group 1), involving 15% of one fragmented core and measuring 1 mm. CMG/SMF/klw/06/08/2017 COMMENT Adenocarcinoma of the prostate, Gleason score 3+4=7 Cristina Magi-Galluzzi, M.D., Ph.D. Tim

Posts.Title: Second Opinion Biopsy - this looks like good news

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DavefromMD Just got the results from my 3 month PSA check. Standard test, < .1, undetectable. Note on my signature that I had a 6mm positive margin, with Gleason 6 at the margin area. I had seen a study that suggested that a margin less than 3mm is insignificant and larger is more signicant, with Gleason at the margin a secondary indicator. I thought the chance of having detectable PSA was greater than undetectable. So for those of you who have a positive margin in the pathology report after surgery, keep the faith! Oh, I guess I now can submit my application to the zero club. Just as additional encouragement, I had an open RP. No catheter issues, kept it cleaned and lubed as instructed. At 2 weeks felt as if I hadn't had major abdominal surgery. I did a lot of pacing in the house while I had the catheter. At 3 weeks I stayed dry overnight. At 10 weeks I stayed dry in daily activities. I'm still working on staying dry when I do anything that compresses or strains the abdomen. According to the docs instructions, I'm on course. Hi Dave; Thanks for posting. I am wondering if you have a link to that study you referred to about a positive margin less than 3mm being insignificant? The information you sent me previously, provides the basis for small positive margins of G6 being insignificant but does not list any particular limits such as 3mm. So I'm wondering if there is a specific study that you can locate ? I know sometimes these studies are difficult to re-locate even after you find them once. Thanks. Tim

Posts.Title: 3 Month Post Op and Encouragement for Those with + Margins

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Prowler My question does not pertain to how a Gleason score is determined, that's defined in every PCa website. My question is whether a tumor with Gleason 4 or 5 cancer cells are a result of Gleason 3 cells that have existed for a longer time and matured into a more aggressive cancer. Or are they different types of prostate cancer that are more aggressive than others. I realize the the more the prostate cancer cell looks less like a prostate tissue cell, the higher the Gleason score. But what makes them be more aggressive? Hello Prowler; There was a research study done which indicates that Gleason Score progression is uncommon. It is generally thought that the grade of prostate cancer remains the same. Here is an article discussing this study - http://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/p...s-201308146604 And if you really want to dig deep, here is a link to the research study - http://cancerres.aacrjournals.org/co...4-ae9e67eaf77f I have mostly G3 but a very small amount of G4 (5%) was detected in two cores which increased my Gleason Sum to 7 (3+4). While one may conclude that the G3 turned into G4 recently, I suppose the G4 could be a new growth. Since the G4 is such a small percentage of the core, I am assuming it started recently. I am getting Robotic RP surgery August 1st to take care of this before the 5% of G4 turns into a higher percentage. Tim

Posts.Title: What does your Gleason score actually mean?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by garyi Great question! I sure hope not. garyi, I am curious why you say you hope not? What other explanation could there be? G4 cells didn't just appear in a split second. In my mind, it only makes sense that time would be the only factor in whether you have a 3+4 or a 4+3 by the very definition of what Gleason scoring is. Say you start out with G3 only in a core. Then your Gleason sum would be 3+3=6. Then a new tumor starts in that same core that is G4. It starts out as a single cell and then continues to multiply faster than a G3. Now you have a Gleason Sum of 3+4. Eventually, if you let the G4 grow long enough, the G4 tumor will get larger than the G3. Now your Gleason Sum is 4+3. Tim

Posts.Content: Hello All; Just thought I'd mention that a doctor from the Cleveland Clinic called today about my two consecutive PSA rises and advised me to make an appointment with a radiation oncologist. I'm really impressed that an actual doctor called and not just a nurse or appointment secretary. He said my PSA isn't rising that fast and he also noted that it was over a year post RP that it started rising so I took these to be good signs. I asked him about my surgeon and he wouldn't give me any details - said he just left the clinic suddenly. I hope nothing bad happened to him like an accident or nervous breakdown. But the big thing I told him when he suggested I make an appointment with a Radiation Oncologist is that I was one step ahead of him and already did ... for next Monday. I also asked him for a few excellent urologist recommendations for followup care as an alternative for my current Nurse Practicioner recommendation and he gave me several. One stuck in my mind so I will likely make an appointment eventually, depending upon what my radiation oncologist says and if or when we will start radiation. Tim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by garyi I assume your CC is the Ohio one. They aren't living up to their sterling reputation. Djin is giving you good advise. I wouldn't be in such a hurry to rush into SRT at your relatively low PSA. Give it some time to settle, and find another RO soon. Thanks or both of your advice, garyi, and Djin and the other folks who offered suggestions too. Yes, garyi - CC is supposed to be #1 in urology, and #5 in cancer. I think my surgeon did pretty good since there were no complications of the actual surgery and he can't see microscopic cancer cells that could escape. Based upon my extensive research and reading some folks BCR even from hospitals more respected than the Cleveland Clinic and even without positive margins. Well I made an appointment with a RO for early in March at a Cleveland Clinic facility near me. I'll see what he suggests. I think I'll ask for monthly ultra sensitive PSA tests just to keep tabs on what my PSA is doing more closely. I am nervous because I want to knock out any remaining cancer cells before they get out of hand. I probably should get a second opinion too from another RO too, perhaps not from the Cleveland Clinic. There are several other pretty good hospitals near me. I see some folks pulling the trigger on SRT at ridiculously low PSA values like .018 providing they see a trend upward. While I've passed .02, I'm willing to pull the trigger too if I see a clear trend upward too after beginning monthly PSA tests. But I'm also anxious to hear what the RO thinks too. I was hoping to delay SRT until I retire next year but that may not be possible to wait that long. Tim

Posts.Title: Need lots of advice - PSA rising - results I didn't want to see

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by meallem I have had prostate cancer for 13 years.in 2004 i had 45 radiations and couple of biopsies.in 2008 i had cryotherapy which did not succeed.i had gleason 7 +7 and maximum 25 psa.after2008. i have been having casodex during the last 9 years which managed to keep down the psa to maximum to 3 .two years ago i had a urine blockage and had to go to hospital .they found that my psa went up to 33 and the cancer got out to the bones. i am treated now with an injection called decaptil each 3 months and stopped the casodex.i started also to take xtandi for the lasr 2 months and i found that i am wanting to sleep all the time.and my urine problems aggavated. i am wondering if some patients are in a similar situiation and what have they done about it.i am 78 years old. Thanks. ezra meallem I don't have any experience with your PCa situation and hopefully never will. However, am wondering if you have diabetes and if so, maybe letting your sugar get past 220? I have type 2 diabetes and if my sugar gets fairly high, I can fall asleep while using the computer while seated in a chair. I end up getting up an hour or so later. This is the only time that seems to happen. It could be a potential explanation. Tim

Posts.Title: I keep falling asleep but no tiredness -advanced prostate canacer.

Posts.Content: Hello All; I went to see my PCP last Friday for a yearly physical - the first physical from him after I had my prostate out. He asked me if I wanted to have a DRE done as he always asks except this time I thought that strange since I thought the purpose of a DRE is to feel the prostate which I no longer had. I reminded him I didn't have a prostate anymore but he said that the purpose of a DRE is to also inspect the rectum for blood so I told him to go ahead. So when I got home, I did some research and found out that indeed a DRE could also be used for other things than a prostate examination. However, I didn't have any indication of any problems in that area. So I thought I'd ask for your thoughts - Do you think it's strange for a doctor to do a DRE with no prostate ? Does your doctor do that ? I also thought after he did it that since I had a very tiny positive margin, what if the doctor disloged a few cancer cells with his finger. Anyway wonder what you think about this ? Tim

Posts.Title: Does this seem stange - PCP did DRE after Prostate Cancer Surgery ?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by sudds63 Hello, Final Report, Prostrate Radical Prostatectomy: Prostatic Adenocarcinoma , poorly differentiated Gleason Score of 4+5=9 (grade 5) Dominant Nodule with a Greatest dimension of 2.4 cm confined within prostate Estimated at 29% of tissue volume (7.14ml) involving surgical resection margins( anterior, at apex); benign seminal vesicles positive for perineral invasions: negative for invasion angiolymphatic invasion no lymph node identified. (NGPIN) High-grade Prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia. Well here it is from my biopsy I was told of Gleason score of 4+3=7 and the final is a 9. The doctor told me that I need 8 to 10 weeks of radiation now because it a more aggressive cancer then thought and I have to get my first post psa test at the end of the mth and that is will determine the amount of weeks I go. He also said its a good thing I got this done now then if I was to wait. I'm worried. I also got so sick after my catheter was removed I got a bad uti with high fever and had catheter put back in for another 8 days because I couldn't pee. Has not been a good week. Also the same week my hot water heater blew and our dog died of cancer, then I got my path report.... Well that's enough thanks for listening. Sudds Sudds; Sorry to hear about the negative pathology report though after radiation, you may still be cured. Interestingly, I got sick the day I had my catheter removed - Not the way you did, but late at night on the day I got my catheter removed, my back started hurting and I couldn't sleep because I couldn't get comfortable ... then the issue seemed to migrate to stomach with extreme pain. It was so bad I decided to check myself into the emergency room at about 3 am. Doc did a CT scan and blood tests and determined that my CT was fine but my pancreas number was higher than normal which the doc said she sees from time to time. She sent me home and the pain finally started to subside. It's now been almost 2 months since that fateful day and the problem never returned (fortunately) so I think it was related in some way to my surgery or catheter removal. Tim

Posts.Title: Got my Path final report back, not good

Posts.Content: Hello All; Looks like I'm heading for salvage radiation. My PSA 3 months ago was .03 and yesterday it is .05. I had surgery by a doctor at the Cleveland Clinic but that doctor apparently left the clinic a few months ago and now I can't even message him. They made me a followup appointment with a Certified Nurse Practitioner for 3 months from now and I can't even message her to have questions answered because apparently you can only message doctors through Mychart. How do I find a Radiation Oncologist ? Are there world class radiation oncologists like there are world class doctors? How do I find one? Should I receive treatment at the Cleveland Clinic or should I travel somewhere ? I really want to do something as soon as possible because .03 to .05 is quite a big jump. If I wait even 3 months, it may jump to .07. Tim

Posts.Title: Need lots of advice - PSA rising - results I didn't want to see

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by garyi I assume your CC is the Ohio one. They aren't living up to their sterling reputation. Djin is giving you good advise. I wouldn't be in such a hurry to rush into SRT at your relatively low PSA. Give it some time to settle, and find another RO soon. Thanks or both of your advice, garyi, and Djin and the other folks who offered suggestions too. Yes, garyi - CC is supposed to be #1 in urology, and #5 in cancer. I think my surgeon did pretty good since there were no complications of the actual surgery and he can't see microscopic cancer cells that could escape. Based upon my extensive research and reading some folks BCR even from hospitals more respected than the Cleveland Clinic and even without positive margins. Well I made an appointment with a RO for early in March at a Cleveland Clinic facility near me. I'll see what he suggests. I think I'll ask for monthly ultra sensitive PSA tests just to keep tabs on what my PSA is doing more closely. I am nervous because I want to knock out any remaining cancer cells before they get out of hand. I probably should get a second opinion too from another RO too, perhaps not from the Cleveland Clinic. There are several other pretty good hospitals near me. I see some folks pulling the trigger on SRT at ridiculously low PSA values like .018 providing they see a trend upward. While I've passed .02, I'm willing to pull the trigger too if I see a clear trend upward too after beginning monthly PSA tests. But I'm also anxious to hear what the RO thinks too. I was hoping to delay SRT until I retire next year but that may not be possible to wait that long. Tim

Posts.Content: redbelly7; The following study (below) demonstrates the benefits of consuming pomegranate juice to slow the progression of Prostate Cancer. Drinking Pomegranate juice is an easy step to take as it could be substituted for your morning orange juice or coffee and it won't hurt but may help. I prefer to juice whole fruit in a vitamix rather than buying juice in a bottle because I'm sure some of the nutrition is lost in the processing and bottling process. Below is an excerpt from the study ... "The most striking evidence for the biological activity of pomegranate extracts was demonstrated in prostate cancer cells. In vivo and in vitro studies have shown that pomegranate extracts are capable of inhibiting tumor cell proliferation, migration, and invasion, while also inducing apoptosis." If you want to read the full article, the link is below ... https://www.hindawi.com/journals/ecam/2013/701434/ Tim

Posts.Title: Severe Incontinence following surgery - Some questions ?

Posts.Content: Hello All; I just got back from the doc's office today and had my doc explain my pathology report but he didn't take too long explaining things. He said my cancer was likely cured. Wonder if anyone can shed some light on your overall impression of the report ... It's pretty detailed and I listed the full report below but I noticed a few things in the report ... 1. Stage PT2: Organ Confined 2. But it also lists a very small positive margin (1mm) which the doctor wasn't too concerned with. Why? 3. Gleason pattern at positive margin - Pattern 3. Full report below ... FINAL DIAGNOSIS 1. Preprostatic fat, excision (A) - Fibromuscular and adipose tissue negative for tumor. 2. Prostatic radical prostatectomy (B) - Adenocarcinoma of the prostate, Gleason score 3+4=7 (Grade Group 2). See synoptic report. - Benign prostatic hyperplasia, glandular and stromal types. - Seminal vesicles are negative for tumor. - Margin of resection is focally positive for tumor. 3. Pelvic lymph node part A, excision (C) - One lymph node, negative for tumor (0/1). 4. Pelvic lymph node part B, excision (D) - Three lymph nodes, negative for tumor (0/3). CMG/kr 08/04/2017 SYNOPTIC REPORT OF KEY PATHOLOGIC FINDINGS PROSTATE: PROSTATE GLAND: RADICAL PROSTATECTOMY Specimen Site: Prostatic structure Tumor Site: Prost ate Areas of involvement: Right posterolateral and posterior apical-mid peripheral zone Principal area of involvement: Right posterolateral and posterior apical-mid peripheral zone Focality: Single nodule Proportion (percentage) of prostate involved by tumor: 10% Procedure: Radical prostatectomy with pelvic lymph node dissection Prostate Size: Size: 5.5cm Size: 4.0cm Size: 4.5cm Prostate Weight: Weight: 69.8 g without seminal vesicle Lymph Node Sampling: Pelvic lymph node dissection Histologic Type: Adenocarcinoma (acinar, not otherwise specified) Primary Gleason Pattern 3 Secondary Gleason Pattern 4 Tertiary Pattern not applicable Total Gleason Score: 7 % of 4 and/or 5: 1-10% % of 3: 91--100% New Grading System: Gleason score 3+4=7: Grade Group 2 Intraductal carcinoma: Intraductal carcinoma not identified Tumor Quantitation: Percentage o f prostate involved by tumor: 10% Tumor size (dominant nodule): Greatest dimension: 20 mm Extraprostatic Extension: Cannot be determined: Tumor is present at the inked margin of resection in an area of capsular incision Urinary Bladder Neck Invasion (Microscopic): Urinary bladder neck invasion microscopic not identified Seminal Vesicle Invasion: Not identified Margins: Margin(s) involved by invasive carcinoma: limited (<3 mm) Linear length of positive margin(s): 1 mm Postero-lateral (neurovascular bundle) margin(s) involved by invasive carcinoma: Right Gleason pattern at positive margin, Pattern 3 Treatment Effect on Carcinoma: Not identified Lymphovascular Invasion: Not identified Pathologic Stage Classification (pTNM, AJCC 7th Edition) TNM Descriptors: Not applicable Primary Tumor (pT): pT2: Organ confined Regional Lymph Nodes (pN): pN0: No positive regional nodes Number of regional lymph nodes examined: 4 Number of regional lymph nodes involved - none identified Distant Metastasis (pM): Not applicable Additional Pathologic Findings: Nodular prostatic hyperplasia Representative Tumor Block: Specify: B16, B13, B11

Posts.Title: Pathology Report - Doc says it's good and I'm likely cancer free but I'm not so sure

Posts.Content: Hello All; I have found that I have severe incontinence following RP. I suppose this is mor or less to be expercted following surgery. I have started doing Kegel Exercises following my surgeon's instructions that I was provided at followup. I assume that improving involves a combination of healing from the surgery (Automatic) and performing regular and lots of daily Kegel Exercises (patient-dependent). I have a couple of questions ... 1. How long did it take for you to begin improving ? 2. Did you do anything spectal to improve faster ? 3. What product(s) have you found to be most effective (Either available locally or mail-order)? I have found that regular Depends briefs seriously leak during the overnight and day as well. Are there any products widely available locally which don't leak ? Right now I am using about 5 or 6 briefs a day - it's that bad. Which means I go through a whole pack in only 4 days. It will cost me big bucks if I have to buy a new pack every 4 days. What strategy have you used to cut down on the number of briefs used per day ? 4. Have any of you tried to use penile clamps and are they effective ? They would seem to be an elegant solution similar to how water is turned off using a valve. Do doctor's recommend them ? Could they cause damage ? Thanks. Tim

Posts.Title: Severe Incontinence following surgery - Some questions ?

Posts.Content: Hi all; I thought I'd report on my continence/incontinence status since I posted a lot about of in the few weeks and months following RALP. It has now been 5 months since surgery and I am doing pretty well with my continence though not perfect (yet). One problem I had that concerned me greatly was my bedwetting fairly long (at least it seemed to me) following surgery. I am happy to report that it appears that has completely gone away. I will wear a belted shield because I appear to pee a very tiny amount but never enough to cause my bed to get wet. I also noticed to my surprise that I seem to be sleeping better and don't need to get up so often at night to urinate. Now I usually get up only one time at night when in the past it used to be 2 or 3 times. Other than that, I do sometimes still have incontinence during the waking hours usually just after I drink something and am standing up. I also have incontinence when i cough or have a bowel movement but I know that is common. For this reason, I always wear a belted shield during the day but I usually only require one during the entire day so its usually not that much of a problem with daily activities. During my 3-month followup with my surgeon and was still having problems I requested and was provided with a physical therapy referral. My first appointment is in a few weeks. Even though I am better now than I was when I saw my surgeon for the followup, I still plan to keep that appointment because I feel it could help me improve the rest of the way quicker. I know there's a lot of interest here on the benefits or lack of benefits from physical therapy so I'll let you know how things go. Tim

Posts.Title: 5 months post-surgery continence status

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another If I had a recurrence the only fact I think I'd want from the surgeon is where did anyting look suspicious to direct the next round of treatment. Unless they made notes I can't imagine they'd remember or even want the responsibility of sharing information like that. I've heard of surgeons sometimes placing clips to mark a spot. Other than that, it's on to the next expert. I was reading this thread and your comment about the "surgeon taking notes" jumped out at me. After my surgery at the Cleveland Clinic, I specifically asked if my surgeon took notes and indeed he did - all three typed pages of them providing a highly detailed explanation of exactly what he did through the entire RP procedure. I couldn't imagine him typing while he was cutting so I'm guessing he spoke them to someone else to type. Maybe all surgeons keep detailed notes on every procedure they do, perhaps now even more to protect themselves from a lawsuit. Dave From MD, you may ask Partin's office he he took notes during your procedure. I would expect any surgeon would be happy to give a patient their notes, especially if they're proud of their work. My surgeon didn't hesitate giving me his notes when I asked for them which I'll take as a sign he was proud of his work . I do want to warn that it's a little strange reading about the procedure that was done on you, but it's also informative. Of course, my doctor and probably yours too used a ton of strange names that you have no idea what they mean unless you google them. I will make another comment. Not sure if Hopkins is different but my surgeon is happy to see me for followup care. I've had two followup visits post-rp and at my 1 year anniversary I see him once a year with quarterly PSA tests. Though perhaps after 5 years of undetectable (fingers crossed) he'll taper off my visits. I wish you the very best of success moving forward, Dave from md. Tim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Prowler My question does not pertain to how a Gleason score is determined, that's defined in every PCa website. My question is whether a tumor with Gleason 4 or 5 cancer cells are a result of Gleason 3 cells that have existed for a longer time and matured into a more aggressive cancer. Or are they different types of prostate cancer that are more aggressive than others. I realize the the more the prostate cancer cell looks less like a prostate tissue cell, the higher the Gleason score. But what makes them be more aggressive? Hello Prowler; There was a research study done which indicates that Gleason Score progression is uncommon. It is generally thought that the grade of prostate cancer remains the same. Here is an article discussing this study - http://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/p...s-201308146604 And if you really want to dig deep, here is a link to the research study - http://cancerres.aacrjournals.org/co...4-ae9e67eaf77f I have mostly G3 but a very small amount of G4 (5%) was detected in two cores which increased my Gleason Sum to 7 (3+4). While one may conclude that the G3 turned into G4 recently, I suppose the G4 could be a new growth. Since the G4 is such a small percentage of the core, I am assuming it started recently. I am getting Robotic RP surgery August 1st to take care of this before the 5% of G4 turns into a higher percentage. Tim

Posts.Title: What does your Gleason score actually mean?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by garyi Great question! I sure hope not. garyi, I am curious why you say you hope not? What other explanation could there be? G4 cells didn't just appear in a split second. In my mind, it only makes sense that time would be the only factor in whether you have a 3+4 or a 4+3 by the very definition of what Gleason scoring is. Say you start out with G3 only in a core. Then your Gleason sum would be 3+3=6. Then a new tumor starts in that same core that is G4. It starts out as a single cell and then continues to multiply faster than a G3. Now you have a Gleason Sum of 3+4. Eventually, if you let the G4 grow long enough, the G4 tumor will get larger than the G3. Now your Gleason Sum is 4+3. Tim

Posts.Title: What does your Gleason score actually mean?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Consult1 From what I have researched, the surgeon will see how easily the tissue peels off at the edges. If it peels off easily, that typically indicates no cancer. If it's sticky, then they either have take out more or do pathology during the surgery to decide (if they have the capability to do that). I rejected my first urologist based on him saying he would automatically take out the nerve bundles based almost solely on my genetic test results. I want someone who will make decisions based on the circumstances they find during the surgery- I wouldn't expect a guarantee of nerve sparing or nerve ending in advance unless there was conclusive evidence from an MRI or some other test. Hey, Consult1; I hadn't thought about it your way but makes lots of sense that nerve sparring is a real-time decision during surgery. I got two opinions for surgery and my first surgeon (Who I thankfully didn't chose) wrote on his notes that he was going to take out one nerve bundle plus 15 lymph nodes (Which seemed really excessive to me) two months before the surgery. He was part of a dedicated urology practice. My other surgeon who I did chose from the Cleveland Clinic did as you said, I believe and decided at surgery time whether or how much of the nerve bundle he wanted to remove or spare and also removed significantly less lymph nodes (4 rather than 15) so now I feel better. Tim

Posts.Title: Nerve Sparing Or Not Nerve Sparing That Is The Question

Posts.Content: Hello All; I thought I'd post some information I discovered recently. You should know that I research everything and this is especially true when it comes to my health. It is generally reported in this forum that Gleason 3+4 behaves almost exactly like 3+3. However, I found this to be only partially true. I received the results of my biopsy second opinion from the Cleveland Clinic and noticed that they added some information that wasn't on the initial biopsy. for my two 3+4 cores, they listed the percentage of pattern 4 which for both cores in my case was 5%. I began investigating further and I found a research study that stated that a 3+4 behaves like a 3+3 and has similar outcomes but only if the percentage of pattern 4 is less than or equal to 6%. See ... https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26750655. Because my second opinion biopsy listed pattern 4 in both cores as 5%, I match the criteria for it acting similar to 3+3 but maybe others may not. I am going to assume that the major hospitals like John Hopkins, etc ... will list the percentage of pattern 4 in a 3+4 or 4+3 sample but smaller hospitals or perhaps mail-order testing labs (Like my initial biopsy) may not. Hopefully the Gleason score won't be upgraded for my final pathology will remain 3+4 or even be reduced to 3+3 - I'll know in about a month. I also found another new piece of data listed on the Cleveland Clinic second opinion pathology report that I didn't see in the initial report. For only the two 3+4 cores, it listed "Cribriform Pattern 4 Not Identified". I wondered what this meant so I began investigating. Apparently, that is a particular apparence of the cells in pattern 4. Anyway, I found another study that stated that outcomes are much better for G3+4 if Cribriform pattern 4 is not present. And they are much worse if Cribriform Pattern 4 IS present. See ... http://www.sciencedirect.com/science...59804916323140. Tim

Posts.Title: Results of two studies - When is the outcome of 3+4=7 similar to 3+3=6?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Consult1 The first test my urologist ordered after the prostate biopsy was a bone scan. I had two cores with Gleason 6 and my PSA was 7.49. Because there was a questionable rib from the scan, I had to endure a stressful bone biopsy which was not a fun way to spend a Friday. Then more stress until the result finally was released a week later, and fortunately it was negative. Since then I have tried to determine if that course of action was appropriate or not. According to Dr. Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer, he doesn't recommend a scan unless the PSA is higher than 20, or Gleason greater than 7, or Stage T3 or greater. This criteria is similar to what Dr. Chodak recommends as he states that 13% of the scans have a questionable result which leads to a biopsy. His statistics are that only 3 of 1000 biopsy's lead to a positive finding for cancer in the bone when that criteria isn't used. Maybe this will help someone in a similar situation. From what I have read a 3T MRI should have been the first test ordered. Are there others with a different take on this? By the way, my first urologist is no longer my urologist. Consult1; So sorry to hear you had to go through a bone biopsy. My urologist had me go through a bone scan only because my biopsy was 3+4. He specifically remarked that if I were a 3+3, it would be a waste of money. And even with a 3+4, he also specifically remarked that with such a low psa as I (5.9), he said he highly doubted that the bone scan would be positive. In addition, when I went through the bone scan, I was a little concerned because the technician said she wanted to take a few extra pictures in case the physician ordered them - so for 2 weeks while waiting for the results, I was worried sick but only found out when I asked the doctor that there was a previous injury to my shoulder (which I didn't even know about). So even though they saw something unusual in the bone scan, the doctor apparently knew that this finding was due to an injury and not cancer. I am not sure why your urologist had you submit to a bone biopsy with only a 3+3 and such low psa (under 10) but I think I would be hesitant to keep that doctor. In my opinion, I would look for a different urologist. Tim

Posts.Title: Bone scan

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by bigalcalbisque Back at home, trying to walk as much as possible. basically around the interior of the house, then resting quite a bit. been passing gas but no bowel movement yet. Pretty chipper mood but ugghh, the dull pain, its not bad its just there and I want to go sparingly on the drugs as I dont want to get constipated as I also have Diverticulosis. Doing pretty decent with my pee bag after the first episode by myself which was not bad if I say so myself. Just a drip from the outer end of the catheter as I am looking at it wondering why it is dripping...oh yeah, my bladder. Quick question, is 2 days without a bowel movement in the normal range and. Back to the pain, it really isn't that bad when I am still, its just when I am moving from 1 position to another, I am assuming that is normal also. Boy what an experience huh? One last thing, my surgery was last Wednesday morning at 8 am and I am scheduled to meet with my Urologist this coming up Tuesday at 12 noon, the Office manager set up the appointment, is that a little too early to get it out or should I just go with the flow and keep that appointment, no pun intended! A big thanks to everybody here that took the time to support me, only forum I have ever been on that was so supportive. You all have helped me more than you will ever know. I am very thankful. Al As I recall, I had my first wattery bM about 4 days after surgery but no real solid BM for quite some time, almost a week post-surgery. I was getting so concerned and even bought prunes to help and that did help for sure. If you had Robotic Surgery and your surgeon did a good job, your catheter should only need to be in for 7-8 days. Mine was. Most surgeons will order a cystogram before they take the catheter out to verify there are no leaks. Sounds like you're doing good and recovering well. Well keep us posted on your progress. Tim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Consult1 From what I have researched, the surgeon will see how easily the tissue peels off at the edges. If it peels off easily, that typically indicates no cancer. If it's sticky, then they either have take out more or do pathology during the surgery to decide (if they have the capability to do that). I rejected my first urologist based on him saying he would automatically take out the nerve bundles based almost solely on my genetic test results. I want someone who will make decisions based on the circumstances they find during the surgery- I wouldn't expect a guarantee of nerve sparing or nerve ending in advance unless there was conclusive evidence from an MRI or some other test. Hey, Consult1; I hadn't thought about it your way but makes lots of sense that nerve sparring is a real-time decision during surgery. I got two opinions for surgery and my first surgeon (Who I thankfully didn't chose) wrote on his notes that he was going to take out one nerve bundle plus 15 lymph nodes (Which seemed really excessive to me) two months before the surgery. He was part of a dedicated urology practice. My other surgeon who I did chose from the Cleveland Clinic did as you said, I believe and decided at surgery time whether or how much of the nerve bundle he wanted to remove or spare and also removed significantly less lymph nodes (4 rather than 15) so now I feel better. Tim

Posts.Title: Nerve Sparing Or Not Nerve Sparing That Is The Question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MrEd That's good news Tim, It's been 2 weeks since I had my PSA check and your post reminded me I did not know my results yet. I called and after waiting for 20 minutes the lady came back and told me it was .1. I asked her is that .1 or <.1. She said it was good and anything less than .25 was good. I said no, its not good and I asked again if there was a less than sign ahead of that .1 and she said "oh yeah there is a less than sign in front of it". I told her to get that posted up in the portal so I could see it. Anyway I guess if your BG was high enough it might put you in a deeper sleep than normal. Also a couple of drinks before sleep could relax you a bit too much but it sounds like your on an average path and doing will. Thanks for the update. Take care. Ed Hi Mr. Ed - Thanks for your comments. Regarding my blood glucose being high, it tends to do the opposite and keeps me up due to urinating a lot more than usual. It doesn't cause me to sleep deeper. This usually happens predictably if I eat something I'm not supposed to so I try to avoid such a situation. So sorry to hear you had to get stressed out by the long wait for your PSA result and the lady who didn't understand the significance of the less-than sign. My result is automatically posted to Mychart at the Cleveland Clinic the day after the blood is drawn. Your result should be posted the day after if done at a major hospital though it could take longer if they have to send it out to a remote lab. Tim

Posts.Content: I search for medical studies very often, not just PCa but about other medical issues and even my favorite topic, healthy eating. I don't think this suggestion was mentioned yet. If I encounter a research study or article that only gives me a summary and charges for the full text, I copy and paste the title to google and can usually find somewhere where the full text is displayed for free. Even if you can't find it for free anywhere (Which in my experience is pretty rare), usually if it's a study of interest to a lot of people, someone will write an article about it somewhere. I have found, though that I am able to read the full text of most any research article that I find without paying for it. Keep in mind, though that especially with medical issues, some text may be difficult to understand if you're not a doctor and familiar with the terminology but usually by skipping to the end, they will include a summary of the results in less technical terms. Oops … sorry Info Gathering. I stand corrected - after I posted this reply, I realize that you posted a reply yesterday that suggested pretty much the same thing. Tim

Posts.Content: Hello All; I just want to report that I got the results of my psa test today and it is undetectable (nine months since surgery). PSA<.03 by the Cleveland Clinic Lab exactly the same value it was last two times (At 1 month post RP and 3 months post RP). Also, continence is good. I only leak in certain stress situations or when I drink a lot of fluid at one time. Bedwetting is still somewhat of a problem but I remain dry most nights. I am beginning to suspect that my Type II diabetes is causing bedwetting if my sugar is higher than normal. Still using belted shields as insurance since they stay in place. Only need one per 24 hour period unless I wet the bed. Would like to downgrade to pads if I can figure out how to keep them in place during movement. Any ideas ? Followup with my Uro Surgeon who did the RP next Wednesday. Tim

Posts.Title: 2 Days After Mr Roboto

Posts.Content: Hi Sma; You would just tell him. Folks can correct me if I'm wrong but I imagine something as large as major robotic prostectomy would require a team of people to accomplish the surgery. However, I believe it is reasonable to expect your surgeon to be at the controls of the robot at all times. It is my understanding that this sometimes doesn't happen with big teaching hospitals as was my case when I had my surgery done at the World Famous Cleveland Clinic. I specifically asked my surgeon if he would be doing the surgery himself and I got a very detailed answer. He said he would be performing all of the major parts himself but there were a lots of other people in my care during the surgery also helping. And this turned out to be a good thing in my case because I had a reaction to the anesthetic and my heart stopped but it was quickly restarted within 20 seconds with no ill effects (Thank goodness). He did say that I can request not so many people present but I told him that was OK and that my only concern was that he was doing the actual surgery. At my first followup when I got my catheter out and my final pathology, I asked for (and was provided) a very detailed report on every step he took to perform the surgery and it was really fascinating to read but he did mention having two surgeon assistants helping with the surgery. The report doesn't specifically state that another surgeon (other than my primary surgeon) did the actual surgery but I believe they did however, I am confident they played a minor role such as opening and closing, etc ... In the end I feel he did a good overall job. Also the report specified that my primary surgeon was present throughout the surgery and was always watching what the assistant surgeons were doing. I did have a very tiny positive margin though not sure who was at the controls to cause that if it could have even been avoided. At 3 months following surgery and my 3-month followup with surgeon this week, I am happy with the overall outcome. If you are having your surgery done at a teaching hospital, you will likely have doctor's assistants helping as that is how doctor's train. If you want your surgeon to perform the full surgery, just tell him. If he refuses, it is within your right to find another surgeon. However, if this is what your surgeon routinely does and you like him and trust him, I don't think I would particularly demand he not use assistants but instead that he do all of the major parts and for those minor parts, he is watching them continuously. Tim

I'll post my post-op psa values tomorrow but I recall every one up until today were <.03. So today, I just lost the less-than sign. I'll post exact data tomorrow. Also, my surgeon has been checking my psa every 3 months and I have my last one ordered (before I see him for a followup) 3 months from now. Do you think 3 months is too long to wait and should I email him and ask him to order a test every month ? I had my last test only 2 months ago and it was <.03. Tim

Posts.Title: BCR? PSA .03 1.3 years after surgery - Advice needed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate There are a number of outdated statements in this post. The possibility of secondary cancers from radiation was true in the 1980's and maybe 1990's, but is insignificant today due to improved technology. Also, if there is a recurrence after primary radiation, that can now be successfully treated by SBRT radiation. So, many of the talking points about surgery having advantages over radiation are no longer true. As Tim admitted, this is a pro-surgery prostate cancer forum. There are others that favor radiation, and still others that favor an alphabet soup of lesser known treatments. You owe it to yourself to get as many opinions as you can. Good luck. ASAAdvocate; I would like to see a non-biased study demonstrating that SBRT (Or other forms of high-energy radiation treatment for Prostate Cancer) doesn't cause secondary cancer's. My statements were based upon the well-known fact that ionization radiation has the ability to initiate cancer growth. Doctor's always downplay the risks because their treatments represent big bucks to them. Obviously, if you have cancer already, then you don't have anything to lose by destroying it with radiation. However, given the choice, I would chose surgery as I did to try to avoid radiation treatment. But as everyone knows here, with Prostate Cancer, even surgery (or radiation) isn't a guarantee of a cure. Tim

Posts.Title: First post and very stressed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Consult1 After a fairly stable PSA of 4.0 (plus/minus 0.15) for 3 straight 6 month readings, it jumped up to 7.49 in May 2017. Biopsy in June revealed left and right apex Gleason 6, one less than 5% and the other core 35%. Dr. ordered an OncotypeDx GPS genetic test on the Gleason 6 cores and it came back high risk- a 43 score. Volume of prostate 50-60 cc. He wanted to schedule surgery with no nerve sparing possibility which sent me into a daze. Got a few other opinions after that, and the Dr. I felt most comfortable with (he started doing DaVinci's in 2003) ordered a 3T MRI which didn't show anything new regarding the prostate but did show a small growth behind the bladder which is probably a liposarcoma. Of the opinions I have sought, only the original Dr. seemed to feel anything unusual on the prostate. At the Cleveland Clinic the urologist said if it wasn't for the genetic test showing high risk, I would have been a perfect candidate for Active Surveillance- his opinion was that I'm a T1c. All urologists with the exception of the first think that nerve sparing is very likely. The original Dr. ordered a bone scan, which revealed one rib with a "lesion", which from what I can tell can mean nothing or something. I've read Gleason 6 almost never spreads beyond the prostate unless the biopsy didn't find the most aggressive portion. But my MRI didn't indicate there was more involved. So I was referred to a Ortho Oncologist and she ordered a bone biopsy (not a lot of fun) and am now waiting for the results with even more stress on top of everything. I will need at least an operation to remove the small tumor, but talked to Radiation Oncologists about Cyberknife and HDR Bracytherapy. While I'm a devout coward when it comes to surgery and at least temporary side effects, it seems to make the most sense to have one operation for both and not go through two different treatments. I'm healthy (other than my stress levels getting my blood pressure up higher than normal) and take no meds. A small aside is that I'm a stomach sleeper, which probably means I wouldn't get good quality sleep with the catheter. Any thoughts from those who have been there and done that would be appreciated. If I've missed anything I will be happy to add details. Hi Consult1; I actually had surgery at the Cleveland Clinic about 1-1/2 weeks ago (August 1, 2017) by Dr. Andrew Stephenson and am recovering at home now. I found that surgery was a breeze with very little to no pain but the catheter (which I thankfully only had for 8 days) was a major pain (literally) - it hurt so bad. Some men don't experience pain like I did, guess I was just unlucky. You will have to put up with sleeping on your back for only a week. Interestingly, I always sleep on my back so wasn't a problem for me but many men who need a catheter don't and they still manage to get through the week OK. Obviously, sleeping on your stomach isn't an option with a catheter. You can read about my complete day-to-day experiences before and after surgery here ... https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...Some-questions As I have learned, most of the people on this forum are pro-surgery. In my case, I wanted to just get rid of the cancer rather than just burn it out with radiation. Plus, Radiation has the potential to lead to secondary cancers. In addition, if you have surgery and your PSA comes back, then you can be treated with radiation to knock out the rest of the cancer. But if you're treated with radiation, and you have a reoccurrence, you generally can't go back and have surgery. So in other words, if your cancer comes back following treatment, you get a second shot at a cure with surgery but not so with radiation. So just my opinion, I think you shouldn't fear surgery and give it a consideration. I am not really familiar with the lab test results you got but I'm sure others will chime in here too with additional insight. A few studies and information seem to indicate that Gleason 6 is not capable of spreading, but some men with Gleason 6 are found to actually have a higher grade of cancer once the full prostate is examined by a pathologist (If you opt for surgery - which is another benefit to having surgery that isn't available with radiation). Fortunately for me, that didn't happen and I remained the same gleason grade that I was on biopsy but others on this forum have been upgraded following surgery when they received the results of their final pathology. It is said to happen in about 20% of cases. Tim

Posts.Title: First post and very stressed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FeatherBoy Regarding urinary ketones. Is your father a diabetic? Please see link below. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ketonuria Yes Keytones can be a problem if your father is diabetic like Featherboy said. Usually a Type 1 Diabetic is my understanding. Also, high keytones can occur if your father is on a very low carb ketogenic diet where he gets most of his energy from fat, less from protein, and hardly none from carbs. I know because I experimented with a very low carb diet several times to try to help my type 2 diabetes and I got some keytones in my urine, even twice on lab tests but I also checked my keytones at home. If you do it through a low carb diet, it's safe but if you generated keytones due to being a type 1 diabetic, it can be life threatening. Also, regarding the biopsy. I had mine (12 core) done under general anesthesia and I didn't feel anything after I woke up from the procedure. I have heard that lots of doctors don't use general anesthesia and instead use local which I hear isn't painful but can be a little uncomfortable. I would think pain wouldn't be a problem with a biopsy though others can chime in if they had other experiences. Tim

Posts.Content: Hello All; I got my quarterly PSA result today and it was an unwelcome .03 (I lost the < sign). Can you give me some advice about what I should do based on the experience of those that have had this happen to them ? Should I wait until my next PSA test in 3 months, or should I request a PSA test every month now? Should I call my surgeon asking for advice or a referral to a Radiation Oncologist ? I was so hoping I would avoid this but I hear stories of this happening on here fairly often. From what I'm reading, the sooner radiation starts after a detectable PSA rise, the better chance for a cure. Thanks. Tim

The possibility of secondary cancers from radiation was true in the 1980's and maybe 1990's, but is insignificant today due to improved technology. Also, if there is a recurrence after primary radiation, that can now be successfully treated by SBRT radiation. So, many of the talking points about surgery having advantages over radiation are no longer true. As Tim admitted, this is a pro-surgery prostate cancer forum. There are others that favor radiation, and still others that favor an alphabet soup of lesser known treatments. You owe it to yourself to get as many opinions as you can. Good luck. ASAAdvocate; I would like to see a non-biased study demonstrating that SBRT (Or other forms of high-energy radiation treatment for Prostate Cancer) doesn't cause secondary cancer's. My statements were based upon the well-known fact that ionization radiation has the ability to initiate cancer growth. Doctor's always downplay the risks because their treatments represent big bucks to them. Obviously, if you have cancer already, then you don't have anything to lose by destroying it with radiation. However, given the choice, I would chose surgery as I did to try to avoid radiation treatment. But as everyone knows here, with Prostate Cancer, even surgery (or radiation) isn't a guarantee of a cure. Tim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Tim! The most important thing to do at this point is: NOT Panic! Your final Path places you in Grade Group 2 which is not high risk. Talk to your URO Surgeon and discuss the implications, if any. Ask when you should repeat the PSA. Be sure your PSAs are being analyzed by The Same Lab Using The Same PSA Methodology each time! Please post the exact Post Op PSA values and dates drawn. Hoping your next PSA is < 0.03! Keep us updated! MF Thanks, Michael for your encouragement and advice not to panic. I'll post my post-op psa values tomorrow but I recall every one up until today were <.03. So today, I just lost the less-than sign. I'll post exact data tomorrow. Also, my surgeon has been checking my psa every 3 months and I have my last one ordered (before I see him for a followup) 3 months from now. Do you think 3 months is too long to wait and should I email him and ask him to order a test every month ? I had my last test only 2 months ago and it was <.03. Tim

Posts.Title: BCR? PSA .03 1.3 years after surgery - Advice needed

Posts.Content: Hello All; I got my quarterly PSA result today and it was an unwelcome .03 (I lost the < sign). Can you give me some advice about what I should do based on the experience of those that have had this happen to them ? Should I wait until my next PSA test in 3 months, or should I request a PSA test every month now? Should I call my surgeon asking for advice or a referral to a Radiation Oncologist ? I was so hoping I would avoid this but I hear stories of this happening on here fairly often. From what I'm reading, the sooner radiation starts after a detectable PSA rise, the better chance for a cure. Thanks. Tim

Posts.Title: BCR? PSA .03 1.3 years after surgery - Advice needed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Consult1 After a fairly stable PSA of 4.0 (plus/minus 0.15) for 3 straight 6 month readings, it jumped up to 7.49 in May 2017. Biopsy in June revealed left and right apex Gleason 6, one less than 5% and the other core 35%. Dr. ordered an OncotypeDx GPS genetic test on the Gleason 6 cores and it came back high risk- a 43 score. Volume of prostate 50-60 cc. He wanted to schedule surgery with no nerve sparing possibility which sent me into a daze. Got a few other opinions after that, and the Dr. I felt most comfortable with (he started doing DaVinci's in 2003) ordered a 3T MRI which didn't show anything new regarding the prostate but did show a small growth behind the bladder which is probably a liposarcoma. Of the opinions I have sought, only the original Dr. seemed to feel anything unusual on the prostate. At the Cleveland Clinic the urologist said if it wasn't for the genetic test showing high risk, I would have been a perfect candidate for Active Surveillance- his opinion was that I'm a T1c. All urologists with the exception of the first think that nerve sparing is very likely. The original Dr. ordered a bone scan, which revealed one rib with a "lesion", which from what I can tell can mean nothing or something. I've read Gleason 6 almost never spreads beyond the prostate unless the biopsy didn't find the most aggressive portion. But my MRI didn't indicate there was more involved. So I was referred to a Ortho Oncologist and she ordered a bone biopsy (not a lot of fun) and am now waiting for the results with even more stress on top of everything. I will need at least an operation to remove the small tumor, but talked to Radiation Oncologists about Cyberknife and HDR Bracytherapy. While I'm a devout coward when it comes to surgery and at least temporary side effects, it seems to make the most sense to have one operation for both and not go through two different treatments. I'm healthy (other than my stress levels getting my blood pressure up higher than normal) and take no meds. A small aside is that I'm a stomach sleeper, which probably means I wouldn't get good quality sleep with the catheter. Any thoughts from those who have been there and done that would be appreciated. If I've missed anything I will be happy to add details. Hi Consult1; I actually had surgery at the Cleveland Clinic about 1-1/2 weeks ago (August 1, 2017) by Dr. Andrew Stephenson and am recovering at home now. I found that surgery was a breeze with very little to no pain but the catheter (which I thankfully only had for 8 days) was a major pain (literally) - it hurt so bad. Some men don't experience pain like I did, guess I was just unlucky. You will have to put up with sleeping on your back for only a week. Interestingly, I always sleep on my back so wasn't a problem for me but many men who need a catheter don't and they still manage to get through the week OK. Obviously, sleeping on your stomach isn't an option with a catheter. You can read about my complete day-to-day experiences before and after surgery here ... https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...Some-questions As I have learned, most of the people on this forum are pro-surgery. In my case, I wanted to just get rid of the cancer rather than just burn it out with radiation. Plus, Radiation has the potential to lead to secondary cancers. In addition, if you have surgery and your PSA comes back, then you can be treated with radiation to knock out the rest of the cancer. But if you're treated with radiation, and you have a reoccurrence, you generally can't go back and have surgery. So in other words, if your cancer comes back following treatment, you get a second shot at a cure with surgery but not so with radiation. So just my opinion, I think you shouldn't fear surgery and give it a consideration. I am not really familiar with the lab test results you got but I'm sure others will chime in here too with additional insight. A few studies and information seem to indicate that Gleason 6 is not capable of spreading, but some men with Gleason 6 are found to actually have a higher grade of cancer once the full prostate is examined by a pathologist (If you opt for surgery - which is another benefit to having surgery that isn't available with radiation). Fortunately for me, that didn't happen and I remained the same gleason grade that I was on biopsy but others on this forum have been upgraded following surgery when they received the results of their final pathology. It is said to happen in about 20% of cases. Tim

Posts.Title: First post and very stressed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Do not pull on the tube to do the lube job for obvious reasons. There is some play, but nothing you want to test. Retract your penis. Thanks for the tip, Another. I actually did try before seeing your post. However, I didn't feel as if it came out any ... perhaps that was good. Interestingly, I called my surgeon's nurse today to try to get some catheter comfort and she pretty much indicated I had to put up with the pain until Wed. I also asked about lubing the tube using the hospital-provided surgilube and she thought it was a bad idea to try to lube the tube as I could inadvertently introduce some germs which could cause a UTI. Of course tomorrow, that may be a non-issue as I have been instructed to take a antibiotic one day before, the day of, and the day after catheter removal. She did say I could lube the tip of my penis but I don't see the sense in that as a way to reduce pain. So I guess I have to live with the pain until Wed. Tim

Dr. ordered an OncotypeDx GPS genetic test on the Gleason 6 cores and it came back high risk- a 43 score. Volume of prostate 50-60 cc. He wanted to schedule surgery with no nerve sparing possibility which sent me into a daze. Got a few other opinions after that, and the Dr. I felt most comfortable with (he started doing DaVinci's in 2003) ordered a 3T MRI which didn't show anything new regarding the prostate but did show a small growth behind the bladder which is probably a liposarcoma. Of the opinions I have sought, only the original Dr. seemed to feel anything unusual on the prostate. At the Cleveland Clinic the urologist said if it wasn't for the genetic test showing high risk, I would have been a perfect candidate for Active Surveillance- his opinion was that I'm a T1c. All urologists with the exception of the first think that nerve sparing is very likely. The original Dr. ordered a bone scan, which revealed one rib with a "lesion", which from what I can tell can mean nothing or something. I've read Gleason 6 almost never spreads beyond the prostate unless the biopsy didn't find the most aggressive portion. But my MRI didn't indicate there was more involved. So I was referred to a Ortho Oncologist and she ordered a bone biopsy (not a lot of fun) and am now waiting for the results with even more stress on top of everything. I will need at least an operation to remove the small tumor, but talked to Radiation Oncologists about Cyberknife and HDR Bracytherapy. While I'm a devout coward when it comes to surgery and at least temporary side effects, it seems to make the most sense to have one operation for both and not go through two different treatments. I'm healthy (other than my stress levels getting my blood pressure up higher than normal) and take no meds. A small aside is that I'm a stomach sleeper, which probably means I wouldn't get good quality sleep with the catheter. Any thoughts from those who have been there and done that would be appreciated. If I've missed anything I will be happy to add details. Hi Consult1; I actually had surgery at the Cleveland Clinic about 1-1/2 weeks ago (August 1, 2017) by Dr. Andrew Stephenson and am recovering at home now. I found that surgery was a breeze with very little to no pain but the catheter (which I thankfully only had for 8 days) was a major pain (literally) - it hurt so bad. Some men don't experience pain like I did, guess I was just unlucky. You will have to put up with sleeping on your back for only a week. Interestingly, I always sleep on my back so wasn't a problem for me but many men who need a catheter don't and they still manage to get through the week OK. Obviously, sleeping on your stomach isn't an option with a catheter. You can read about my complete day-to-day experiences before and after surgery here ... https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...Some-questions As I have learned, most of the people on this forum are pro-surgery. In my case, I wanted to just get rid of the cancer rather than just burn it out with radiation. Plus, Radiation has the potential to lead to secondary cancers. In addition, if you have surgery and your PSA comes back, then you can be treated with radiation to knock out the rest of the cancer. But if you're treated with radiation, and you have a reoccurrence, you generally can't go back and have surgery. So in other words, if your cancer comes back following treatment, you get a second shot at a cure with surgery but not so with radiation. So just my opinion, I think you shouldn't fear surgery and give it a consideration. I am not really familiar with the lab test results you got but I'm sure others will chime in here too with additional insight. A few studies and information seem to indicate that Gleason 6 is not capable of spreading, but some men with Gleason 6 are found to actually have a higher grade of cancer once the full prostate is examined by a pathologist (If you opt for surgery - which is another benefit to having surgery that isn't available with radiation). Fortunately for me, that didn't happen and I remained the same gleason grade that I was on biopsy but others on this forum have been upgraded following surgery when they received the results of their final pathology. It is said to happen in about 20% of cases. Tim

Posts.Title: First post and very stressed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate There are a number of outdated statements in this post. The possibility of secondary cancers from radiation was true in the 1980's and maybe 1990's, but is insignificant today due to improved technology. Also, if there is a recurrence after primary radiation, that can now be successfully treated by SBRT radiation. So, many of the talking points about surgery having advantages over radiation are no longer true. As Tim admitted, this is a pro-surgery prostate cancer forum. There are others that favor radiation, and still others that favor an alphabet soup of lesser known treatments. You owe it to yourself to get as many opinions as you can. Good luck. ASAAdvocate; I would like to see a non-biased study demonstrating that SBRT (Or other forms of high-energy radiation treatment for Prostate Cancer) doesn't cause secondary cancer's. My statements were based upon the well-known fact that ionization radiation has the ability to initiate cancer growth. Doctor's always downplay the risks because their treatments represent big bucks to them. Obviously, if you have cancer already, then you don't have anything to lose by destroying it with radiation. However, given the choice, I would chose surgery as I did to try to avoid radiation treatment. But as everyone knows here, with Prostate Cancer, even surgery (or radiation) isn't a guarantee of a cure. Tim

Posts.Content: I am 2-1/2 months post surgery and still have fairly bad incontinence. I have noticed an improvement since the first month when I was really, really bad but still have squirting everytime I get up and also sometimes walk. For the first two months post surgery, I needed a diaper but now at 2-1/2 months post surgery I found out that I am able to get through the day with one belted shield. I am also experiencing wetting the bed at night at 2-1/2 months post surgery. Not sure why that is a problem but hoping that goes away in time. So for some reason, I am being slow to recover my continence. I have tried every manner of thing to control my incontinence. I tried a penile clamp but found it to be too uncomfortable so don't use it that often except for very short periods. I've tried an external condom catheter with a long tubing and leg bag but found the adhesive used by the condom to be too unfomfortable too so I stopped using it. Then one of the fellas on here told me about the AlphaDry Condom Catheter by Urodry and I have found it to be an amazing product. It does have some minor problems like mild leaking and some irritation at times but it is by far the best of all of the products I used. It's expensive but I have found it to be reusable for a month or more. I used to use it everyday for work but now I only use it at night due to my bedwetting. For work, I now use a belted shield and so far, I have only needed one a day. Hope all of this info helps. Good luck in returning to continence faster than I am. Tim

"Percent free not reported when Total and/or Free PSA value is below the lower limit of detection." I am going to call the hospital to get a quote on the cost of PSA and Free PSA (Which includes PSA) to see what the cost difference is between these two tests. Tim

Palpation suggest no prostate adhesions and he will be performing a single incision RALP Monday outpatient....I believe it is recommended to have a liquid diet following surgery but I am curious why this is, and how soon (days?) generally until I could have solid food ? 3. Am curious how long your hospital stay was and if there were any complications in your case ? I was told by a nurse 2-3 days but most everywhere I read seems to indicate only overnight....I wanted that cancerous thing out of my body permanently! While I could have had the surgery closer to home, my urologist recommended either Johns Hopkins or Cleveland Clinic....Perhaps the doctor will eventually suggest radiation too after getting the final pathology report after surgery but hopefully not. I would feel better just to have the whole prostate removed....While I could have had the surgery closer to home, my urologist recommended either Johns Hopkins or Cleveland Clinic. I'm located about equidistant from both, and elected to go to Cleveland....That's why I personally opted for surgery. Perhaps the doctor will eventually suggest radiation too after getting the final pathology report after surgery but hopefully not....I was able to get a copy of the surgeon's notes and he stated "Given the patient's age, PSA value, volume of disease, and Gleason Score, curative therapy was recommended. Patient has elected to proceed with LEFT nerve sparing robotic-assisted laproscopic prostatectomy/BPLND)"....
